posts.title: Buying a Home? Here's How We Rank Area Schools
posts.markdown: I'm buying a home... is the school good? Seems like a simple question, right? For professional real estate agents and brokers, it's not so simple. An agent can't steer their client toward a particular school. The only thing an agent can ethically do is recommend their clients call the school, research online or go to one of the many school ranking websites. So what’s the problem? School ranking websites often have flawed ranking systems. There are two main issues with how school ranking sites work today as it relates to educating a home buyer: **1. Most ranking websites factor in both objective and subjective data.** Objective data focuses on test scores that are submitted to the U.S. Department of Education and can be easily obtained by anyone. But subjective data is collected from, well, people. Because this data comes from people, it's often skewed, or not truly representative. For example, how many people get on a soapbox and tell people how good things are? Let’s be honest, not many. However, people are much more prone to complaining when something is wrong. So, there is often an abundance of negative information about a school and not much positive information. Is this really how you, as a potential home buyer, want to make a decision on a home purchase? **2. Schools receiving identical scores.** School ranking sites make it difficult to differentiate between schools in an area when they are given an identical score. How can home buyers make an educated decision when all the schools you are looking at have an “A” rating or are all ranked “10”? From an educational standpoint, it's great when many schools in an area receive the same high rankings, and it’s what we all want as parents. But parents also have to make tough financial decisions. So, if there is a way to differentiate one “A” school from the next “A” school, that information is mission critical. Since it's so hard to differentiate among good schools, the current state of school ranking websites offers minimal assistance, if any, when it comes to making a home buying decision. What options do you have? The team at Cruvita has created a solution to help parents make the right decision when buying a home. By developing the Cruvita School Score and applying it to over 50,000 schools across the United States, home buyers can be sure they are not just buying a home, they are buying the right home. Not only have we applied the Cruvita School Score to over 50,000 schools nationwide, we have also ranked the schools in three separate geographic areas -- the city/county, the state, and the nation -- to help you compare schools on a deeper level. **How the Cruvita School Score Was Developed** First, we only use objective data. This way, we can't be swayed by the court of public opinion. And, our objective data is a lot more than just test scores. We can’t tell you our patent-pending algorithm, but what we will say is we use educational data and several other pieces of socioeconomic data, including housing trends, to develop our score. Although it’s not unheard of, it’s incredibly difficult to have two schools with the same score, eliminating the problem of not being able to differentiate between the top schools. Though the ranking is self-explanatory, the score itself does take a little getting used to. The lower the score, the better the school. If you are considering moving to a new location, use the Cruvita School Score to help you make an educated decision. Or you can use it to see where your current school ranks. Just go to our [school score rankings page](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings) and enter the area you want to live in, or the actual school name you are interested in. We currently have home listings available in the DC Metro Area (Virginia and Maryland), the Hampton Roads/Tidewater area of Virginia; Palm Beach County, Florida; and the Raleigh-Durham area of North Carolina. Listings in the area will have the nearest schools on the actual listing with their scores, so you can invest in the right home for your family. Visit us at [www.Cruvita.com](http://www.cruvita.com) to search for your next home.

posts.title: 5 Reasons Agents Should Use ‘Value Added’ Real Estate Syndication Sites
posts.markdown: Value added real estate syndication websites are more than just a source for home listings. They can focus on a niche in the marketplace. Some focus on neighborhoods, high end listings, or in Cruvita’s case, education. If properly utilized, they can help agents in many ways. Here are five positive ways sites like [Cruvita.com](http://www.cruvita.com) can help agents and brokers: **An Educational Resource for Your Client** ![](/content/images/2015/06/B9---School-Page-v3-3.png) Some of the toughest questions realtors are asked include, “What neighborhood is the best?” or our favorite, “Which school is the best?” The problem is, real estate agents can't steer a client to a particular neighborhood or school. They can, however, direct their clients to a site that has [independently ranked schools](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings) in the nation. Another benefit of using a site like Cruvita is that the work has been done for you. Your clients can easily search in their desired school district for homes. Simply email them to yourself so you can verify they are still available and set up showings. It’s a win-win for all. **Better Reach for Real Estate Listings** ![](/content/images/2015/06/B9---better-reach-for-listings-v2.png) Some agents or brokers feel that sending their listings to syndication sites is diluting their site or devaluing the MLS in general. But that is not the case. If you think back to 15+ years ago, agents would pay to have their listings in local newspapers and magazines to get additional exposure. Even today this is commonplace. Having your listings syndicated increases your reach exponentially. The overlap between real estate sites is not that great. Once a user finds what they like, they stick with it. With niche sites becoming more the norm, sites like Cruvita allow your listings to reach a very specific audience that, in turn, becomes your client! **Additional Exposure for You** As mentioned above, niche site reach unique audiences that might otherwise never see you. The obvious benefit is when a potential client contacts you directly. But branding is another benefit that should not be ignored. Having potential customers see your name, picture or company has a value that cannot be defined, but overtime could be the little nudge that causes a person to contact you over other Realtors. **Be an Expert on a Specific Location** Being an expert for a particular location, or in Cruvita’s case a school, allows you to break away from the pack of agents, and really present your value proposition to potential clients. **Leads** Whether it's phone calls, emails or clicks to your website, any lead is a good lead! The bottom line is don't be afraid to use a value added niche site like Cruvita.com for any combination of the above reasons. If you have questions about this article, or Cruvita, feel free to [email us](mailto:news@cruvita.com) or visit us at [Cruvita.com](http://www.cruvita.com). ![](/content/images/2015/06/Sales---Leads-3-d-render---680.png)

posts.title: 10 Simple Steps to Help First-Time Homebuyers
posts.markdown:
As Generation X-ers move into middle age, we are seeing fewer of them as first-time homebuyers. Now we see Millennials looking to become homeowners. What can be done to make their lives a little easier? What may seem common knowledge to you may not be to someone who is living in a fast paced digital world. Below are 10 simple steps that potential homebuyers should know before they start their home buying process. **Know Your Budget** What may seem simple actually isn’t. While interest rates are still relatively low, they still fluctuate. Factor in variable down payments, and possible mortgage insurance premiums, and what a buyer thinks they can spend may not be the case. Before embarking on a house hunt, use simple tools to reverse engineer what you want your monthly payment to be. Simply search for [Mortage Calculator](https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=mortgage%20calculator), or better yet talk to a mortgage broker... **Mortgage Broker** Roughly [60 percent of homebuyers](http://www.marketwatch.com/story/43-of-2014-home-buyers-paid-all-cash-2014-05-08) rely on some sort of financing. Most first-time homebuyers fall in this segment. Make sure proper due diligence is done. Research and good old-fashioned phone calling are a must. Also, be sure to contact your existing bank. Some banks offer incentives for existing customers. When looking at a mortgage of 30 years, saving 1/10 of a percent can save thousands over the life of a loan. **Get Your Paperwork Ready** This may have already been taken care of during preliminary conversations with a mortgage broker, but if not, get everything ready. If possible, get everything in digital format: previous 2+ years of tax returns, pay stubs and bank statements. **Check for Available First-Time Homebuyer Programs** Simply doing a web search for first-time homebuyer programs will get you plenty of results, but be sure to look at the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development website. They have a special section dedicated to local programs you can review by [clicking here](http://portal.hud.gov/hudportal/HUD?src=/topics/rental_assistance/local). **New Construction vs Resale Homes** Everyone loves a new home, but there are pros and cons to consider. Make sure the buyers know the deposit to build is NOT the deposit needed for their mortgage. **See as Many Homes as Possible** While looking at homes, make a list of the "must-haves" and then the wish list. Something as simple as this can really help identify the proper home. **Location** Location, Location, Location. Make sure the location selected meets the current and future needs of the homebuyer. Are children in the plans? Is the property in the best school district? Use resources such as [Cruvita.com](http://www.Cruvita.com) to identify specifics on the property being reviewed. Remember agents can't steer clients towards a particular neighborhood or even a school district. This is when having sites like Cruvita can make a big difference. **After the Offer is Made** After the prospective buyer makes an offer, what happens next? It’s NOT straight to the closing table. A home inspection needs to happen. This is not to be confused with the home appraisal which will be ordered by the lending institution. Keep in mind if the buyer is getting an FHA Loan a second appraisal may be ordered. Also, after the inspection, what if items need to be fixed? Will there be concessions? This is when having a seasoned real estate agent/broker can make all the difference. **The Closing Process** Has the loan been approved by underwriting? Have the funds been cleared? How do the funds need to be paid by the buyer? Knowing in advance all of these things can make the day of closing a lot less stressful. **Moving Day** First, find the right moving company. Second, make sure all utilities are set up and ready to go. In some instances a copy of the HUD Statement may be needed from the closing. Make sure digital copies are readily available. When it comes time to find the right home, be sure to use [Cruvita.com](http://www.Cruvita.com). And if needed, contact one of the Cruvita Home Sales Experts to help.
![](/content/images/2015/06/Bought-a-New-House-collage---resize-640w.png)

What may seem common knowledge to you may not be to someone who is living in a fast paced digital world. Below are 10 simple steps that potential homebuyers should know before they start their home buying process.

Know Your Budget

What may seem simple actually isn’t. While interest rates are still relatively low, they still fluctuate. Factor in variable down payments, and possible mortgage insurance premiums, and what a buyer thinks they can spend may not be the case. Before embarking on a house hunt, use simple tools to reverse engineer what you want your monthly payment to be. Simply search for Mortage Calculator, or better yet talk to a mortgage broker...

Mortgage Broker

Roughly 60 percent of homebuyers rely on some sort of financing. Most first-time homebuyers fall in this segment. Make sure proper due diligence is done. Research and good old-fashioned phone calling are a must. Also, be sure to contact your existing bank. Some banks offer incentives for existing customers. When looking at a mortgage of 30 years, saving 1/10 of a percent can save thousands over the life of a loan.

Get Your Paperwork Ready

This may have already been taken care of during preliminary conversations with a mortgage broker, but if not, get everything ready. If possible, get everything in digital format: previous 2+ years of tax returns, pay stubs and bank statements.

Check for Available First-Time Homebuyer Programs

Simply doing a web search for first-time homebuyer programs will get you plenty of results, but be sure to look at the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development website. They have a special section dedicated to local programs you can review by clicking here.

New Construction vs Resale Homes

Everyone loves a new home, but there are pros and cons to consider. Make sure the buyers know the deposit to build is NOT the deposit needed for their mortgage.

See as Many Homes as Possible

While looking at homes, make a list of the "must-haves" and then the wish list. Something as simple as this can really help identify the proper home.

Location

Location, Location, Location. Make sure the location selected meets the current and future needs of the homebuyer. Are children in the plans? Is the property in the best school district? Use resources such as Cruvita.com to identify specifics on the property being reviewed. Remember agents can't steer clients towards a particular neighborhood or even a school district. This is when having sites like Cruvita can make a big difference.

After the Offer is Made

After the prospective buyer makes an offer, what happens next? It’s NOT straight to the closing table. A home inspection needs to happen. This is not to be confused with the home appraisal which will be ordered by the lending institution. Keep in mind if the buyer is getting an FHA Loan a second appraisal may be ordered. Also, after the inspection, what if items need to be fixed? Will there be concessions? This is when having a seasoned real estate agent/broker can make all the difference.

The Closing Process

Has the loan been approved by underwriting? Have the funds been cleared? How do the funds need to be paid by the buyer? Knowing in advance all of these things can make the day of closing a lot less stressful.

Moving Day

First, find the right moving company. Second, make sure all utilities are set up and ready to go. In some instances a copy of the HUD Statement may be needed from the closing. Make sure digital copies are readily available.

When it comes time to find the right home, be sure to use Cruvita.com. And if needed, contact one of the Cruvita Home Sales Experts to help.

posts.title: Less Is More – When You Search For Homes with Cruvita
posts.markdown: On [Cruvita.com](http://www.cruvita.com) the lower the school scores the better! Currently there are over 50,000 schools ranked on [Cruvita.com](http://www.Cruvita.com) and more are being added daily. The best school has a ranking score of .02 which is the cream of the crop, while the worst school has a score of 17955688.778. If you want to look through our entire rankings please [click here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings). The distinct advantage with the Cruvita School Score is that you can compare different areas at an almost microscopic level. By removing an arbitrary 1-10 ranking scale and giving you a true numeric value, you can easily look at schools and see how they rank against each other. We have taken the effort to factor in the school performance and socioeconomic indicators to aid homebuyers in making educated decisions on the largest purchases in their life. To get the Cruvita School Score, information has been collected and analyzed from multiple sources including: The United State Department of Education, The United States Census Bureau and current home sale trends. Specific data points have been pulled from these sources and inserted into an algorithm that is truly unique in the real estate market. No other real estate or education site, ranks schools the way we do. This allows the homebuyer to learn about the homes listed while gaining an understanding of the schools and the quality of their investment. To further aid visitors color association and a ranking system have been applied to each school. The colors range from green to deep red. Green means the school is very good. The farther away from green you go, the higher the school’s score is. Remember, the lower the score, the better the school. [![](/content/images/2015/06/B2---less-is-more.png)](http://www.cruvita.com/learn) The Cruvita Medal of Excellence was developed to help users easily identify the best schools in a geographic region. Each school is ranked in its city/county, state and in the nation. When reviewing schools on Cruvita you will see one of the medals. In the below image you see schools that have achieved medal status in all three categories. When you mouse over the school rank you can see how many schools are in that geographic area, and it adds an additional icon on the map where the school is actually located. ![](/content/images/2015/06/B2---School-Rank-info.png) So try using [Cruvita.com](http://www.cruvita.com/) to search for a home. Tell us what you think about the school scoring system and how it can help you find your next home.

posts.title: Why Are Good Schools Important to Homebuyers?
posts.markdown: If you are in the market for a new home, there are many factors to consider. One of the more important factors, though sometimes overlooked, is the quality of the school district where the home is located. Whether you have children or not, there are plenty of good reasons to strongly consider the quality of the neighborhood schools. **Property Value** Even if you don't plan to have children, you should consider the quality of the school district you are in. Why? Most people want to live in a good school district, which means demand for your home will be high. High demand means your home value will likely see a healthy appreciation. In 2014, Realtor.com's [Back To School Survey](http://www.realtor.com/news/back-to-school-home-search-tips/) found that the majority of homebuyers said school boundaries has an impact on their home purchasing decision. They also found that some homebuyers were willing to pay as much as 10 percent above budget to live in their desired school district. ![](/content/images/2015/06/Home-Value-Rising---680.png) **Weather The Next Financial Storm Better** Economic downturns are just a fact of life. It's not if they will happen, but when they will happen. The good news is that you are more likely to get through it with less financial damage if you own a home in a good school district. In 2011, data analysis company [Location, In](http://blogs.wsj.com/developments/2011/11/16/one-antidote-to-foreclosures-good-schools/)c conducted a study on home foreclosures in five metro areas (Jacksonville, Fl; Atlanta, Ga; Toledo, Oh; Stockton, Ca.; and Seattle, Wa). They found that well regarded school districts suffered fewer foreclosures. They also maintained higher home sale prices. ![](/content/images/2015/06/Financial-Storm--640.png) **Better Liquidity** One of the few potential downsides to homeownership is that it ties you to a location until you are able to sell your home (unless you have the ability and tolerance to rent it out). Even if you plan on being in your new home for a very long time, it's always nice to know that if something comes up and you want (or need) to move, you are able to do it with relative ease. Since you will be living in a highly desirable neighborhood with good schools, the higher demand means it should take you less time to sell your home. The quality of the school district may not be the overriding factor in your home-buying decision, but as you can see, it can be important for more reasons than most people realize. Granted, homes in quality school districts tend to be a little more expensive (in property value and taxes), but as long as it fits into your budget, it will be well worth your while, whether you have kids or not. If there is a specific school or area you have targeted search for the school rankings at [www.cruvita.com/rankings](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings).

posts.title: Top 10 Elementary Schools in Prince William County Virginia
posts.markdown:
Prince William County is the second largest county in Virginia and is nestled between Fairfax and Stafford Counties. The county has the benefit of having two major interstates, I-66 and I-95, making commutes into Fairfax and Washington DC easy to navigate. *Editor’s note: we said easy to navigate, not necessarily quickly, especially during rush hour.* Over the past 20 years Prince William County in Virginia has seen an incredible amount of [population growth](http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/states/51/51153.html). Because of that, cities such as Manassas, Manassas City and Woodbridge are considered great places to live more affordably, while still being able to commute around the DC Metro area. Places such as Haymarket, Bristow and Gainesville are also garnering attention as places to settle down and raise a family. And other cities such as Dale City, Dumfries, and surrounding areas are being recognized as great places to live. The areas mentioned are all continuing to grow in popularity as the DC Metro Area continues its need to expand. As a whole the schools in the county are above average, but listed below are the top 10 elementary schools. Two of the schools, Mary G. Porter and Pennington School, are non-traditional schools. posts.html:
Prince William County is the second largest county in Virginia and is nestled between Fairfax and Stafford Counties. The county has the benefit of having two major interstates, I-66 and I-95, making commutes into Fairfax and Washington DC easy to navigate. Editor’s note: we said easy to navigate, not necessarily quickly, especially during rush hour.

Over the past 20 years Prince William County in Virginia has seen an incredible amount of population growth. Because of that, cities such as Manassas, Manassas City and Woodbridge are considered great places to live more affordably, while still being able to commute around the DC Metro area. Places such as Haymarket, Bristow and Gainesville are also garnering attention as places to settle down and raise a family. And other cities such as Dale City, Dumfries, and surrounding areas are being recognized as great places to live. The areas mentioned are all continuing to grow in popularity as the DC Metro Area continues its need to expand.

As a whole the schools in the county are above average, but listed below are the top 10 elementary schools. Two of the schools, Mary G. Porter and Pennington School, are non-traditional schools. posts.title: Top 10 Elementary Schools in Arlington County, Virginia
posts.markdown: Arlington County, Virginia, is situated along the Potomac River, right across from Washington, D.C., and is also bordered by Fairfax County, Virginia, and the City of Alexandria. The county’s close proximity to downtown Washington, D.C., and vast public transportation options make commuting downtown much easier and shorter than many of the county’s Metropolitan Area counterparts. [*Forbes*](http://www.forbes.com/2007/12/12/best-places-for-education-oped-cx_dsa_1212educate.html) ranks Arlington County the top place in the nation to educate your child, and with many fantastic schools and easy access to national parks, museums, and memorials, it’s easy to see why more and more families are moving to Arlington County, Virginia. posts.title: Top 10 Elementary Schools for Homebuyers in Chesapeake Virginia
posts.markdown: Chesapeake, Virginia, located in the Hampton Roads metro area, is the 3rd most populous city in Virginia. North Carolina is its southern border, and it is connected to Norfolk, Virginia Beach, Suffolk and Portsmouth making it an ideal location to settle down and avoid some of the urban sprawl. The schools in Chesapeake are some of the best in the state. Seven of the elementary schools are ranked in the top 25% of Virginia according to Cruvita.com. The Top school in Chesapeake is Butts Road Intermediate. An interesting point is the use of intermediate and primary schools. While they are both classified as elementary schools the population of an area dictates whether they will have a traditional elementary school (k-5) or a combination of primary (k-2) & intermediate (3-5). Chesapeake, Virginia, located in the Hampton Roads metro area, is the 3rd most populous city in Virginia. North Carolina is its southern border, and it is connected to Norfolk, Virginia Beach, Suffolk and Portsmouth making it an ideal location to settle down and avoid some of the urban sprawl.

The schools in Chesapeake are some of the best in the state. Seven of the elementary schools are ranked in the top 25% of Virginia according to Cruvita.com. The Top school in Chesapeake is Butts Road Intermediate. An interesting point is the use of intermediate and primary schools. While they are both classified as elementary schools the population of an area dictates whether they will have a traditional elementary school (k-5) or a combination of primary (k-2) & intermediate (3-5).

To learn more about the schools in Chesapeake, and to see the entire list of schools, please click here.

posts.title: Fairfax County vs Montgomery County: Where Should I Live?
posts.markdown: Fairfax County and Montgomery County may share the border between Virginia and Maryland, but they may as well be a world away, if you ask some of the residents in each county. That's because they are so often considered competitors for people looking to live in the Washington DC area. Let's just say there's a bit of a neighborly rivalry. If you're thinking about living and/or working in either county, here are some of the most important factors to consider: **Population** The 2014 estimate for the population of each county are as follows: Montgomery County: 1,030,447 Fairfax County: 1,137,538 According to the most recent IRS migration statistics, 2,155 people moved to Fairfax County from Montgomery County in 2007, while 1,776 came to Montgomery from Fairfax. Though, in the previous year, the migration rate slightly favored Montgomery County, 2,162 to 2,126. **School Quality** Whether you are buying a home or renting, parents want the best educational opportunities for their kids. As we mentioned in a previous blog, even if you don't have children, there are good reasons to consider the quality of the school district you are living in. Both Fairfax County and Montgomery County have some of the best schools in the nation. Let's take a look at how the top schools in each county compare: Elementary schools - The top elementary school in Montgomery County (according to the Cruvita scoring system) is [Bradley Hills Elementary School](http://www.cruvita.com/school/bradley-hills-elementary-bethesda-md) in Bethesda, Maryland. We also have it ranked as the number one school in Maryland, and seventh in the United States. The top elementary school in Fairfax County is [Wolftrap Elementary School](http://www.cruvita.com/school/wolftrap-elem-vienna-va) in Vienna, Virginia. It also ranks first in Virginia, but "only" 37th in the United States. Winner: Montgomery County Middle schools - The top middle school in Montgomery County is [Thomas W. Pyle Middle School](http://www.cruvita.com/school/thomas-w-pyle-middle-school-bethesda-md), also in Bethesda, Maryland. It also ranks first in the state and seventh in the nation. The best middle school in Fairfax County is [Cooper Middle School](http://www.cruvita.com/school/cooper-middle-mclean-va) in McLean, Virginia. It ranks second in the state and 84th in the nation. Winner: Montgomery County High schools - The top high school in Montgomery County is [Walt Whitman High School](http://www.cruvita.com/school/walt-whitman-high-bethesda-md) in Bethesda, Maryland, which is also fourth in the state and 88th in the nation. The best school in Fairfax County is [Thomas Jefferson High School](http://www.cruvita.com/school/thomas-jefferson-high-alexandria-va) in Alexandria, Virginia. It ranks third in the state and 14th in the nation. Winner: Fairfax County To be fair, this is only a comparison of the single best schools in each county, not the counties as a whole. That said, as you can see the area schools rank well at the state level and compete at national levels as well. **Job Opportunities** According to 2010 data from the Montgomery County Office of Legislative Oversight, Fairfax County had about 200,000 more jobs than Montgomery County. The March 2015 unemployment numbers from the Bureau of Labor Statistics show that Fairfax County has a very slight edge on Montgomery County, with a 3.9 and a 4.0 unemployment rate respectively. Both are well below the 5.6 percent national average. In 2011, Forbes ranked Fairfax County as the third wealthiest county in nation, with an annual median household income of $104,259, which is all the more impressive with its considerably high population of more than 1.1 million residents. In 2011, Montgomery County had a median household income of $92,213, making it the 10th richest county in the U.S. One of the key reasons the Fairfax County job market is so strong is its dominance in the federal government job sector. According to the U.S. Department of Commerce, Fairfax County had 107,597 public sector jobs in 2007, compared to 88,488 in Montgomery County. But it's not just about direct employment with government agencies, companies that depend on federal dollars for their business, such as Freddie Mac or any number of government contractors, prosper in their close proximity to Washington DC and the favorable tax structure of Fairfax County. One of the reasons Fairfax County has a higher volume of job opportunities comes down to the amount of land available for commerce. Montgomery County's Office of Legislative Oversight said that 38 percent of its land is saved in agricultural preservation programs and parkland, whereas Fairfax County has 15 percent of its land reserved for parkland. **Taxes** Outside of a few relatively minor exceptions, Fairfax County wins the battle for better tax rates. Fairfax County residence, on average, tend to be wealthier and taxed less than their Montgomery County counterparts. For instance, the personal income tax range in Montgomery County is 5.2 to 9.45 percent, while Fairfax County's range is 2 to 5.75 percent. The corporate income tax rate in Montgomery County is 8.25 percent, compared to Fairfax County's 6 percent rate. Fairfax County does have a Business/Professional/Occupational License tax, which is only about $30-$50, if gross receipts are under $100,000, but above that, a rate is set based upon the business classification. **Housing Market** According to the [United States Census Bureau](http://factfinder.census.gov/faces/nav/jsf/pages/index.xhtml), the median home value in Fairfax County is $476,600, and $446,300 in Montgomery County. The DC area remains one of the more expensive housing markets in the country, due in large part to the high paying jobs and job security that often comes with government-related careers. **Recreational Activities** Both Montgomery County and Fairfax County share the luxury of neighboring Washington DC with its rich history, on display in everything from historical government buildings to the vast educational opportunities in the Smithsonian Institute's museums. But both counties have their fair share of interesting activities. In fact, the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum is in Chantilly, located in Fairfax County. Also, one of the most historically significant homes in our nation's history is located in Fairfax County: George Washington's Mount Vernon estate. Montgomery County boasts over 33,000 acres of parkland in over 400 parks, so obviously outdoor activities abound here. Since agricultural land is plentiful, you can also support Montgomery County farmers and eat fresh and healthy by attending the farmers markets. Of course, Montgomery County isn't all parks and farmland. There are plenty of cultural activities, including The Strathmore arts center or the Sugarloaf Craft Festivals, where you can enjoy the works of talented artisans. There are many things to consider if you're debating which county is best for you. Everyone's individual needs and interests will dictate most of the decision making process. Hopefully this helps at least get the ball rolling for you.
posts.html:
Fairfax County and Montgomery County may share the border between Virginia and Maryland, but they may as well be a world away, if you ask some of the residents in each county. That's because they are so often considered competitors for people looking to live in the Washington DC area. Let's just say there's a bit of a neighborly rivalry.

If you're thinking about living and/or working in either county, here are some of the most important factors to consider:

Population

The 2014 estimate for the population of each county are as follows:

Montgomery County: 1,030,447
Fairfax County: 1,137,538

According to the most recent IRS migration statistics, 2,155 people moved to Fairfax County from Montgomery County in 2007, while 1,776 came to Montgomery from Fairfax. Though, in the previous year, the migration rate slightly favored Montgomery County, 2,162 to 2,126.

School Quality

Whether you are buying a home or renting, parents want the best educational opportunities for their kids. As we mentioned in a previous blog, even if you don't have children, there are good reasons to consider the quality of the school district you are living in.

Both Fairfax County and Montgomery County have some of the best schools in the nation. Let's take a look at how the top schools in each county compare:

Elementary schools - The top elementary school in Montgomery County (according to the Cruvita scoring system) is Bradley Hills Elementary School in Bethesda, Maryland. We also have it ranked as the number one school in Maryland, and seventh in the United States.

The top elementary school in Fairfax County is Wolftrap Elementary School in Vienna, Virginia. It also ranks first in Virginia, but "only" 37th in the United States.

Winner: Montgomery County

Middle schools - The top middle school in Montgomery County is Thomas W. Pyle Middle School, also in Bethesda, Maryland. It also ranks first in the state and seventh in the nation.

The best middle school in Fairfax County is Cooper Middle School in McLean, Virginia. It ranks second in the state and 84th in the nation.

Winner: Montgomery County

High schools - The top high school in Montgomery County is Walt Whitman High School in Bethesda, Maryland, which is also fourth in the state and 88th in the nation.

The best school in Fairfax County is Thomas Jefferson High School in Alexandria, Virginia. It ranks third in the state and 14th in the nation.

Winner: Fairfax County

To be fair, this is only a comparison of the single best schools in each county, not the counties as a whole. That said, as you can see the area schools rank well at the state level and compete at national levels as well.

Job Opportunities

According to 2010 data from the Montgomery County Office of Legislative Oversight, Fairfax County had about 200,000 more jobs than Montgomery County.

The March 2015 unemployment numbers from the Bureau of Labor Statistics show that Fairfax County has a very slight edge on Montgomery County, with a 3.9 and a 4.0 unemployment rate respectively. Both are well below the 5.6 percent national average.

In 2011, Forbes ranked Fairfax County as the third wealthiest county in nation, with an annual median household income of $104,259, which is all the more impressive with its considerably high population of more than 1.1 million residents. In 2011, Montgomery County had a median household income of $92,213, making it the 10th richest county in the U.S.

One of the key reasons the Fairfax County job market is so strong is its dominance in the federal government job sector. According to the U.S. Department of Commerce, Fairfax County had 107,597 public sector jobs in 2007, compared to 88,488 in Montgomery County.

But it's not just about direct employment with government agencies, companies that depend on federal dollars for their business, such as Freddie Mac or any number of government contractors, prosper in their close proximity to Washington DC and the favorable tax structure of Fairfax County.

One of the reasons Fairfax County has a higher volume of job opportunities comes down to the amount of land available for commerce. Montgomery County's Office of Legislative Oversight said that 38 percent of its land is saved in agricultural preservation programs and parkland, whereas Fairfax County has 15 percent of its land reserved for parkland.

Taxes

Outside of a few relatively minor exceptions, Fairfax County wins the battle for better tax rates. Fairfax County residence, on average, tend to be wealthier and taxed less than their Montgomery County counterparts. For instance, the personal income tax range in Montgomery County is 5.2 to 9.45 percent, while Fairfax County's range is 2 to 5.75 percent. The corporate income tax rate in Montgomery County is 8.25 percent, compared to Fairfax County's 6 percent rate.

Fairfax County does have a Business/Professional/Occupational License tax, which is only about $30-$50, if gross receipts are under $100,000, but above that, a rate is set based upon the business classification.

Housing Market

According to the United States Census Bureau, the median home value in Fairfax County is $476,600, and $446,300 in Montgomery County. The DC area remains one of the more expensive housing markets in the country, due in large part to the high paying jobs and job security that often comes with government-related careers.

Recreational Activities

Both Montgomery County and Fairfax County share the luxury of neighboring Washington DC with its rich history, on display in everything from historical government buildings to the vast educational opportunities in the Smithsonian Institute's museums. But both counties have their fair share of interesting activities.

In fact, the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum is in Chantilly, located in Fairfax County. Also, one of the most historically significant homes in our nation's history is located in Fairfax County: George Washington's Mount Vernon estate.

Montgomery County boasts over 33,000 acres of parkland in over 400 parks, so obviously outdoor activities abound here. Since agricultural land is plentiful, you can also support Montgomery County farmers and eat fresh and healthy by attending the farmers markets.

Of course, Montgomery County isn't all parks and farmland. There are plenty of cultural activities, including The Strathmore arts center or the Sugarloaf Craft Festivals, where you can enjoy the works of talented artisans.

There are many things to consider if you're debating which county is best for you. Everyone's individual needs and interests will dictate most of the decision making process. Hopefully this helps at least get the ball rolling for you.

posts.title: Top 10 Schools in Stafford County, Virginia
posts.markdown: Stafford County, Virginia, is located across the Rappahannock River from the city of Fredericksburg, and is part of the DC metropolitan area. With major highways such as Interstate 95, US 17 and US 1 running through the county, it is easy to be connected to everything in Northern Virginia. This historic area is where founding fathers George Washington and George Mason grew up, and is rich in history from the first settlers. In more modern times, it is appealing to homebuyers who want to be close to cities like Fredericksburg, and still have access to Washington, D.C., and Richmond, Virginia. **Here are the top 10 schools in Stafford County, VA:** **1. posts.title: Best Schools for Homebuyers in Hampton Roads, Virginia
posts.markdown:
The Hampton Roads area of Southeastern Virginia is found on the coast of Virginia and is part of the Virginia Tidewater Region. This metropolitan area is made up of independent cities— the City of Chesapeake, the City of Franklin, the City of Hampton, the City of Newport News, the City of Norfolk, the City of Poquoson, the City of Portsmouth, the City of Suffolk, the City of Virginia Beach, and the City of Williamsburg. The Hampton Roads area is proudly known as “America’s First Region,” and is full of history that is fun for all ages, including Historic Jamestown and the Jamestown Settlement, as well as Colonial Williamsburg. The region is also home to many of the state’s finest and most beautiful beaches. The harbor was the key to Hampton Roads’ growth, and many of the top industries there revolve around the harbor, such as shipbuilding. The United States Military has a large presence in the region, which is home to over 20 U.S. Military facilities. Other top employers in the region include the many colleges and universities in the area, such as the College of William & Mary, Old Dominion University, and Christopher Newport University. Besides the beautiful beaches, the rich history, and one of the best and largest parks systems in the nation, Hampton Roads is also home to some great schools. It’s a great place for homebuyers to invest— not only in a home, but also in their children’s futures’. Cruvita has listed below the best schools in Hampton Roads, Virginia, to help you with your search to find not just any home, but the right home. posts.title: 9 Things I Wish I Knew Before I Bought My House
posts.markdown: After dealing with finding a house, the closing process, and then moving, you are finally in your perfect home. The walls are perfectly painted, blinds are set and the candles are lit. Everything is perfect… until the unforeseen happens. You have no recourse. All you can do is grin and bear it. If you are already dealing with any unforeseen problems, you can’t go back in time and get another home. All you can do is sell your house, if that's a realistic option, or just deal with it. However, if you haven't bought the home of your dreams yet, it's not too late! Here are the top 9 things people wish they knew before they bought their new home: **1. THE INTERNET SERVICE IS TERRIBLE** If you are reading this, you know just how intertwined the Internet is in our daily lives. What would happen if you moved where the Internet service providers (ISPs) weren’t that good? Would you live off your 4g hotspot? Not exactly cost effective. While there is no way to guarantee quality Internet service in your future home, a little leg work goes a long a way. Do a quick Internet search for ISPs in the area you are thinking about moving to. Look for a minimum of two service providers for that area. We have found that areas with competition tend to have better overall service for their subscribers. If you're lucky, a provider such as Verizon or Google is bringing fiber into your area. **2. No Cell Phone Coverage** Is having your cell phone constantly drop calls your worst nightmare? This can happen due to a lack of coverage in the area you are home shopping. The best way to avoid cell phone reception problems is, when you are looking at homes, check your cell phone. Make sure you have ample coverage. Also, check at various places in the house (the kitchen, living room, bedrooms, etc.). While it might not be a deal breaker for you, some homes are so well built that the cell signal can’t penetrate through every room. **3. Too Much Noise Caused by Planes or Trains** This is a tough one. Your best bet is to make sure you are working with a good Realtor who knows the area you are looking at. Be sure to ask what airports and railroad tracks are nearby. Are you in the flight pattern? Is it a commuter or freight rail line? Some people can sleep through anything, but a plane flying overhead can shake a house. Just imagine what a freight train sounds like at four in the morning! Do your due diligence and ask questions. **4. The Neighbors are a Nightmare** This could very well be every homebuyer’s worst fear: bad neighbors. They could have a messy yard, have loud parties all the time, block your driveway, or simply be nasty people. One of the only ways you can avoid this is to meet them before you purchase a home. We know people who before making an offer went and knocked on doors to meet their potential neighbors. At the very least, do a drive-by at different parts of the day. Get an idea not only about your direct neighbors, but people down the street. Don’t be afraid to ask people about the neighborhood if you see them walking. Their reaction could be a good indication as to what you can expect if you purchase the home. **5. The Smell!** Unforeseen smells may only be second to bad neighbors. When looking at a home, be sure to ask about nearby garbage or recycling areas. Also, ask about wetlands. If you are near a creek bed or marshlands the smell of sulfur could very easily make its way to you perfect home if the winds shift. **6. No Nearby Entertainment** You move into a new area and there is nothing to do without taking a long drive. Think about the activities you want to be within close proximity of your home. For instance, find out where the closest movie theaters are, nice restaurants, or any other recreational activities that are important to you. http://blog.cruvita.com/ghost/ **7. Poor Access to Job Centers** Imagine finding your perfect home, then realizing you have to leave it earlier than expected because your commute is way too long. We recommend driving the route to work during rush hour to get a good grasp of your commute, or ask your realtor if they have experience with the traffic. **8. Lack of Public Transportation** Some people either don’t like to drive, or simply don’t drive at all, and depend on public transportation. If you need it, make sure it's offered in the area before you move. **9. The Schools are Bad!** Thankfully you have us to help you with that. You can find the right school, then buy your next home using [Cruvita.com](http://www.cruvita.com)!
posts.html:
After dealing with finding a house, the closing process, and then moving, you are finally in your perfect home. The walls are perfectly painted, blinds are set and the candles are lit. Everything is perfect… until the unforeseen happens.

You have no recourse. All you can do is grin and bear it.

If you are already dealing with any unforeseen problems, you can’t go back in time and get another home. All you can do is sell your house, if that's a realistic option, or just deal with it.

However, if you haven't bought the home of your dreams yet, it's not too late! Here are the top 9 things people wish they knew before they bought their new home:

1. THE INTERNET SERVICE IS TERRIBLE

If you are reading this, you know just how intertwined the Internet is in our daily lives. What would happen if you moved where the Internet service providers (ISPs) weren’t that good? Would you live off your 4g hotspot? Not exactly cost effective.

While there is no way to guarantee quality Internet service in your future home, a little leg work goes a long a way.

Do a quick Internet search for ISPs in the area you are thinking about moving to. Look for a minimum of two service providers for that area. We have found that areas with competition tend to have better overall service for their subscribers. If you're lucky, a provider such as Verizon or Google is bringing fiber into your area.

2. No Cell Phone Coverage

Is having your cell phone constantly drop calls your worst nightmare? This can happen due to a lack of coverage in the area you are home shopping.

The best way to avoid cell phone reception problems is, when you are looking at homes, check your cell phone. Make sure you have ample coverage. Also, check at various places in the house (the kitchen, living room, bedrooms, etc.). While it might not be a deal breaker for you, some homes are so well built that the cell signal can’t penetrate through every room.

3. Too Much Noise Caused by Planes or Trains

This is a tough one. Your best bet is to make sure you are working with a good Realtor who knows the area you are looking at. Be sure to ask what airports and railroad tracks are nearby. Are you in the flight pattern? Is it a commuter or freight rail line?

Some people can sleep through anything, but a plane flying overhead can shake a house. Just imagine what a freight train sounds like at four in the morning! Do your due diligence and ask questions.

4. The Neighbors are a Nightmare

This could very well be every homebuyer’s worst fear: bad neighbors. They could have a messy yard, have loud parties all the time, block your driveway, or simply be nasty people.

One of the only ways you can avoid this is to meet them before you purchase a home. We know people who before making an offer went and knocked on doors to meet their potential neighbors.

At the very least, do a drive-by at different parts of the day. Get an idea not only about your direct neighbors, but people down the street. Don’t be afraid to ask people about the neighborhood if you see them walking. Their reaction could be a good indication as to what you can expect if you purchase the home.

5. The Smell!

Unforeseen smells may only be second to bad neighbors. When looking at a home, be sure to ask about nearby garbage or recycling areas. Also, ask about wetlands. If you are near a creek bed or marshlands the smell of sulfur could very easily make its way to you perfect home if the winds shift.

6. No Nearby Entertainment

You move into a new area and there is nothing to do without taking a long drive. Think about the activities you want to be within close proximity of your home. For instance, find out where the closest movie theaters are, nice restaurants, or any other recreational activities that are important to you. http://blog.cruvita.com/ghost/

7. Poor Access to Job Centers
Imagine finding your perfect home, then realizing you have to leave it earlier than expected because your commute is way too long. We recommend driving the route to work during rush hour to get a good grasp of your commute, or ask your realtor if they have experience with the traffic.

8. Lack of Public Transportation
Some people either don’t like to drive, or simply don’t drive at all, and depend on public transportation. If you need it, make sure it's offered in the area before you move.

9. The Schools are Bad!

Thankfully you have us to help you with that. You can find the right school, then buy your next home using Cruvita.com!

posts.title: The Top 100 Schools for Homebuyers in the RTP / Raleigh-Durham Metro Market
posts.markdown:
The Raleigh-Durham-Chapel Hill Research Triangle is in the center of North Carolina and is formed by North Carolina State University (Raleigh), Duke University (Durham), and University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (Chapel Hill). There are multiple definitions of The Research Triangle region, but the broadest definition of the area includes 15 counties: Chatham County, Durham County, Edgecombe County, Franklin County, Granville County, Harnett County, Johnston County, Lee County, Moore County, Nash County, Orange County, Person County, Vance County, Wake County, and Warren County. Durham County, Orange County and Wake County are the three principal counties that make up the core of the Research Triangle and include the principal cities of Durham and Raleigh and the principal town of Chapel Hill. The Research Triangle region originally drew in high-tech businesses and enterprises because of the proximity to three major research universities and the development of Research Triangle Park. The region has developed further and drawn in businesses outside of the high-tech realm. Top businesses in the region include Bayer, Cisco Systems, General Electric, IBM, Progress Energy, Red Hat Inc. and SAS Institute, to name a few. With leading technology firms, world-class universities, medical centers and schools, the area’s economy has performed exceptionally well and significant growth is projected over the next 15 years. The Research Triangle region of North Carolina has an incredible amount to offer homebuyers, including great schools. Many of the schools in this area have Cruvita Gold Medals of Excellence, or rank in the top 5 percent, for the city/town, the state, and the nation! Cruvita has listed below the best schools in the Raleigh-Durham-Chapel Hill Research Triangle area to help you with your search to find not just any home, but the right home. For more information about the school, simply click on the name and you will be redirected to that school’s page on Cruvita. James City County is located on the Virginia Peninsula and is often grouped with the Hampton Roads Metropolitan Area of independent cities. posts.markdown:
![](http://) Located on the southeastern end of the Virginia Peninsula, the City of Hampton is one of the seven major cities that compose the Hampton Roads Metropolitan Area. Hampton, Virginia, was also home to the first free public school in the United States, and Hampton City Public Schools continue to flourish today. Raleigh, North Carolina, is located in the center of the state and is the state capital, as well as the county seat for Wake County. posts.title: Top 15 Schools for Homebuyers in Arlington County, Virginia
posts.markdown:
Arlington County, Virginia, is situated in Northern Virginia on the south bank of the Potomac River directly across from Washington, D.C. Arlington is also bordered by Fairfax County, the City of Falls Church and the City of Alexandria. The county’s proximity to downtown Washington, D.C. and vast public transportation options make commuting downtown much easier and shorter than many of the county’s Metropolitan Area counterparts. [Forbes](http://www.forbes.com/2007/12/12/best-places-for-education-oped-cx_dsa_1212educate.html) ranked Arlington County the top place in the nation to educate your child, and with many fantastic schools and easy access to national parks, museums, and memorials, it’s easy to see why more and more families are moving to Arlington County, Virginia. posts.title: Why Live in Chesapeake Virginia
posts.markdown: Today in our continuing series on “Why Live in” we explore Chesapeake, VA. Chesapeake is in the Hampton Roads metro area, is an independent city and has been ranked one of the fastest growing cities in Virginia. Bordering Norfolk, Portsmouth and Virginia Beach, Chesapeake has easy access to some of the major job centers in the region. If you are a nature lover Chesapeake has miles of waterfront property and is home to the [Great Dismal Swamp National Wildlife Refuge](http://www.fws.gov/refuge/Great_Dismal_Swamp). Here are a few quick highlights: * Estimated Household Income: $67,200 * Estimated Home Value: $254,000 * Unemployment Rate: 4.70% There are several great schools and amazing homes available in Chesapeake. posts.title: Top 10 Elementary Schools for Homebuyers in St. Mary's County, Maryland
posts.markdown:
St. Mary's County, Maryland, is located in the southern part of Maryland and is included in the Baltimore-Washington Metropolitan Area. St. Mary's County is traditionally known for its unique and historic culture of Chesapeake Bay tidewater farming, fishing and crabbing communities, and has grown significantly over the last few decades as more D.C. commuters have moved to the area. Listed below are the top 10 elementary schools for homebuyers looking to move to St. Mary's County, Maryland. One of the schools listed below has received a Cruvita Gold Medal of Excellence at the national level, and nine of the schools have received Cruvita Silver Medals of Excellence at the national level. To see a list of all of the schools in St. Mary's County, Maryland, [click here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?locationcounty=st-marys-county-md). To view all of the homes for sale or for rent in St. Mary's County, Maryland, [click here](http://www.cruvita.com/results?location=st-marys-county-md-y&tab=homes). **Here are the top 10 elementary schools in St. Mary's County, Maryland:**
Rank School City Click to View Available Homes
1 Evergreen Elementary School California
2 Leonardtown Elementary School Leonardtown
3 Lettie Marshall Dent Elementary School Mechanicsville
4 White Marsh Elementary School Mechanicsville
5 Chesapeake Charter School Lexington Park

7 Oakville Elementary School Mechanicsville

9 Hollywood Elementary School Hollywood
10 Town Creek Elementary School Lexington Park

Hampton is an independent city in the Hampton Roads Metropolitan Area and is surrounded by several major highways and has many public transportation options. **Here are a few quick highlights:** * Estimated Population: 136,500 * Estimated Median Household Income: $43,750 * Estimated Home Value: $185,200 * Unemployment Rate: 6.20% There are several great schools and amazing homes in Hampton, Virginia. Eight of the schools in Hampton have received Cruvita Bronze Medals of Excellence at the national level, which you can see [here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?locationcity=hampton-va), or you can see their position on a map by clicking [here](http://www.cruvita.com/results?location=hampton-va-c&tab=schools). posts.title: Top 75 Schools for Homebuyers in Prince George's County, Maryland
posts.markdown:
Bordering the eastern part of Washington, D.C., Prince George’s County, Maryland, is a great place for those who work in the District to find a home to raise their families. With many major highways and public transportation options, and some great schools and homes, it's easy to see why Prince George's County, Maryland, is such a popular place for families to settle. Major cities in the county include Bowie, College Park, Hyattsville, New Carrollton, Capital Heights, Cheverly, Upper Marlboro, and Beltsville. Listed below are the top 75 schools (at all levels) for homebuyers looking to move to Prince George's County, Maryland. Four of the schools listed below have received Cruvita Gold Medals of Excellence, six have received Cruvita Silver Medals of Excellence, and 59 of the schools below have received Cruvita Bronze Medals of Excellence at the national level. To see the rankings of all of the schools in Prince George's County, Maryland, [click here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?locationcounty=prince-georges-county-md). posts.title: Top 10 Schools for Homebuyers in Allegany County, Maryland

posts.title: You Found the Perfect Home, But How are the Schools?
posts.markdown: You have spent weeks looking for the perfect home. After countless hours driving from home to home you finally find the one you have been looking for. But, as you are doing your due diligence you ask your real estate agent about the schools. While you are expecting a simple answer like, “the schools are great!” or “the schools are terrible,” you get an unexpected response. Your agent asks you to contact the local school district. That seems pretty archaic in these technologically advanced times. To be fair, your real estate agent is limited in how they can help in this regard. Fair housing laws that are designed to prevent discrimination dictate that they are not allowed to give their opinions on the quality of the schools in the area of the home you want to buy. Fortunately for you, Cruvita.com has no such restrictions. Enter the Cruvita School Finder. Using the Cruvita School Finder is incredibly easy. First, on your computer or mobile device, go to [www.cruvita.com/cruvita-school-finder](http://www.cruvita.com/cruvita-school-finder). Simply enter the address for the home you need information on, then click the **Find My Schools** button. ![](/content/images/2015/12/Cruvita-School-Finder--main-v2.JPG) After that you can quickly see the schools that are associated with the address and their Cruvita School Grade. If you need additional information, the schools are hyperlinked so you can quickly get additional information on the school(s) in question. ![](/content/images/2015/12/Cruvita-School-Finder--results-v2-1.JPG) **Haven't Found Your Dream Home Yet? Even Better!** If you are in the market, but haven't settled on the home of your dreams, it might be a good thing, since you can first make sure it's located in an ideal school district. There's good reason for you to want quick and easy access to school quality information. Being able to quickly educate yourself on the quality of the schools for a specific home could be the difference between making a timely offer that gets you to the closing table or making an offer just after someone else has a signed contract on your dream home. What if you don't have kids? What if you don't even plan to have kids? School districts are still very much worth your consideration. In fact, according to the 2014 National Association of Realtors' Profile of Home Buyers and Sellers, 29 percent of home buyers considered school quality and 22 percent considered proximity to schools as deciding factors for their home buying decision. Let's be clear: they aren't saying just "a" factor, but a "deciding" factor. If you are in a great school district, not only does this make your property more likely to appreciate than homes in subpar school districts, you should be able to sell it quicker, since it will be in high demand. If you are currently home shopping or soon will be, whether you have children or not, the Cruvita School Finder should be a tool that is bookmarked and ready to use. Try it for yourself and let us know what you think!

Fort Worth, Texas, is the fifth largest city in Texas and the 16th largest city in the United States. Located in the northeastern portion of the state, this major city is part of the Dallas-Fort Worth-Arlington Metropolitan area and has a population of roughly 812,250 people. Major companies based in Fort Worth include American Airlines Group, the John Peter Smith Hospital, Pier 1 Imports, RadioShack, and the BNSF Railway. Known as “The City of Cowboys and Culture,” Fort Worth, Texas, has a strong focus on local arts, and is also home to the world’s largest indoor rodeo. posts.html:
The County of Los Angeles, California, is located on the Pacific Coast of Southern California and is part of the Los Angeles Metropolitan Area. Los Angeles County is best-known for its county seat, Los Angeles, its extraordinary ethnic diversity, and the entertainment industry. Los Angeles County, California has an estimated population of 10.1 million people and a median home value of $420,300. The county is home to many sports teams and a very active arts and entertainment industry, and is also served by a number of major highways, airports, ferries, and public transportation options.

Listed below are the top 40 elementary schools for homebuyers in the County of Los Angeles, California. Four of the schools below have received Cruvita Gold Medals of Excellence at the national level. The best of the bunch is Opal Robinson Elementary in Manhattan Beach, CA.

posts.title: Top 20 Elementary Schools for Home Buyers in Washtenaw County, MI
posts.markdown:
Washtenaw County, Michigan is located in southeast Michigan about 30 miles west of Detroit. The largest city in the county is Ann Arbor. Other major cities include Saline, Dexter, Chelsea and Ypsilanti. Washtenaw County has a population of just over 357,000 people and a median home or condo value of $199,200. The University of Michigan is in Ann Arbor, MI, while the county is also home to other major colleges and universities such as Eastern Michigan University and the Ann Arbor campus of the Thomas M. Cooley Law School. Listed below are the top 20 elementary schools for homebuyers in Washtenaw County, Michigan. Twelve of the schools listed below have received Cruvita Medals of Excellence at the national level. The best being [Martin Luther King Elementary School](http://www.cruvita.com/school/martin-luther-king-elem-school-ann-arbor-mi) in Ann Arbor, which received a silver medal! “In this business, one of the first things I hear from my buyer is “We are interested in living within this school district,” says [Middy Matthews from Keller Williams in Ann Arbor, MI](http://arbormove.com/). “In Ann Arbor we pride ourselves on our schools and our teachers. While every school and community in the area are exceptional, where the kids play and how they get to school is critical. Our parents are involved and interested in making childhood a unique and magical experience. As a Realtor, I certainly understand the need to make sure your vision is actuated. When my clients lead in with a choice in schools, I immediately send them to Cruvita to learn more and start the home search process. Cruvita has been a time saver and one stop research tool for my clients from schools to homes.” If you would like to see Washtenaw County's high school or junior high/middle school rankings click the appropriate link below: [Best High Schools for Homebuyers in Washtenaw County](http://blog.cruvita.com/best-high-schools-for-home-buyers-in-washtenaw-county-mi/) [Best Junior High or Middle Schools for Homebuyers in Washtenaw County](http://blog.cruvita.com/best-junior-high-or-middle-schools-in-washtenaw-county-mi/) To see a list of all of the public schools in [Washtenaw County, Michigan](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=washtenaw-county-mi&type=county), and their Cruvita School Scores, [click here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=washtenaw-county-mi&type=county). **The Best Elementary Schools for Homebuyers in Washtenaw County, Michigan:**

Bexar County, Texas has an estimated population of 1.855 million people and a median home value of $123,700. The county is home to the nation’s first digital library. posts.title: Why Live in Dallas, Tarrant, or Denton County Texas?
posts.markdown: [Cruvita.com](http://www.cruvita.com) gives facts on why to live in Dallas, Tarrant or Denton County. If you are looking for a place to live in the Dallas–Fort Worth–Arlington area, but have some flexibility of where you decide to land, it's important to weigh all the factors that impact your decision-making process, whether it's financial, educational, or quality of life. Here is a comparison of some of the pertinent factors in Dallas, Tarrant and Denton Counties: #### **Population:** The 2014 estimate from the US Census for the population of each county are as follows: Tarrant County: 1,945,360 Dallas County: 2,518,638 Denton County: 753,363 According to IRS migration statistics, Denton County experienced the 7th highest net migration gain of any county in the United States, with 12,461 more residents from 2013 to 2014. That migration came pretty much equally from inside and outside the state. Tarrant County saw a 5,059 net gain in migration from 2013 to 2014, while Dallas County had a net loss of 4,797 people. #### **School Quality** Everyone should care about the quality of the schools in their neighborhood, whether you have children or not. Parents want great schools for their children for obvious reasons. But living in a great school district also means the properties are more likely to appreciate at a greater rate than other neighborhoods, and they also tend to be safer places to live. When comparing the school quality of Dallas, Tarrant and Denton counties, there are several ways to go about it. We can look at the big picture and use the Cruvita letter grades for the top schools in each county. Cruvita's algorithm pools together various important factors, crunches the numbers, and comes up with a numerical and letter grade for the school being evaluated. The letter grade was the latest addition to our website and it makes for an easy and intuitive way for our users to see which schools "make the grade" and which do not. If we look at the very best of the best in each county -- those that achieved an A+ rating from Cruvita -- here is how many are located in each: [Denton County](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=denton-county-tx&type=county) - 33 [Tarrant County](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=tarrant-county-tx&type=county) - 28 [Dallas County](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=dallas-county-tx&type=county) - 15 This acts as a nice starting point, because it gives a good indication of how each county performs overall, or at least which ones have the most schools that achieve a perfect rating. However, you're only going to be living in one school district, and if you are a parent, sending your child to one school. So it's more important to look at schools individually. Let's take a look at which schools top the list for each county, then compare the three counties: #### **Elementary Schools** The top elementary school in Dallas County, as ranked by the Cruvita scoring system, is [Bradfield Elementary](http://www.cruvita.com/school/bradfield-elementary-dallas-tx). It has achieved an A+ rating and is first in Dallas, the state, and the nation. To see all the [elementary schools in Dallas County click here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=dallas-county-tx&type=county&edLevel=1). The top elementary school in Tarrant County is [Robert H. Rockenbaugh Elementary](http://www.cruvita.com/school/robert-h-rockenbaugh-el-southlake-tx), which has received an A+ rating from Cruvita and is number one in Southlake, 10th in Texas, and 28th in the nation. To see all the [elementary schools in Tarrant County click here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=tarrant-county-tx&type=county&edLevel=1). The top elementary school in Denton County is [Wellington Elementary](http://www.cruvita.com/school/wellington-elementary-flower-mound-tx) in Flower Mound, Texas. It achieved an A+ rating from Cruvita and is number one in Flower Mound, 9th in Texas. and 26th in the nation. To view [the top elementary schools in Denton County click here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=denton-county-tx&type=county&edLevel=1). *Winner: **Dallas County*** While Dallas County had the fewest A+ rated schools among the three counties, its top school beat the top schools coming from Tarrant and Denton Counties. #### **Middle Schools** The top middle school in Dallas County is [Mcculloch Intermediate School](http://www.cruvita.com/school/mcculloch-intermediate-school-dallas-tx). Located in Dallas, it is number one in the city, state, and the nation. [Click here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=dallas-county-tx&type=county&edLevel=2) to view the [top middle or intermediate schools in Dallas County](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=dallas-county-tx&type=county&edLevel=2). The top middle school in Denton County is [Griffin Middle School](http://www.cruvita.com/school/griffin-middle-school-frisco-tx) in Frisco, Texas. It has achieved an A+ rating and is number one in Frisco, number seven in the state, and number 33 in the nation. To view the [top middle, junior high, or intermediate schools in Denton County click here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=denton-county-tx&type=county&edLevel=2). The top middle school in Tarrant County is [George Dawson Middle](http://www.cruvita.com/school/george-dawson-middle-southlake-tx) in Southlake, Texas. It is number one in Southlake, fourth in the state, and 12th in the nation. To see all [the middle, junior high or intermediate school in Tarrant County click here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=tarrant-county-tx&type=county&edLevel=2). *Winner: **Dallas County*** #### **High Schools** The top high school in Dallas County is [Highland Park High School](http://www.cruvita.com/school/highland-park-high-school-dallas-tx). It has an A+ rating, and is first in Dallas, the state, and is second in the nation. To see all the [high schools in Dallas County click here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=dallas-county-tx&type=county&edLevel=3). The top high school in Denton County is [Flower Mound High School](http://www.cruvita.com/school/flower-mound-h-s-flower-mound-tx) in Flower Mound, Texas. It received an A+ rating from Cruvita, and is first in Flower Mound, second in Texas, and 71st in the nation. To see all the [high schools in Denton County click here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=denton-county-tx&type=county&edLevel=3). The top high school in Tarrant County is [Keller High School](http://www.cruvita.com/school/keller-h-s-keller-tx) in Keller, Texas. It has an A+ rating and is first in Keller, 31st in Texas, and 436th in the nation. [Click here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=tarrant-county-tx&type=county&edLevel=3) to see all the [high schools in Tarrant County, TX](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=tarrant-county-tx&type=county&edLevel=3). *Winner: **Dallas County*** While this is only a comparison of the best schools in each county, not the counties as a whole, the results are very interesting. While Dallas County had the fewest A+ rated schools, it still had the best elementary school, middle school, and high school among all three counties. #### **Job Opportunities** **Dallas County** As of April 2015, the unemployment rate in Dallas County was 3.9 percent, much lower than the national average of 6 percent of the time. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, there were 1,558,500 people employed in the third quarter of 2014, which had it ranked second among the largest counties in Texas, right behind Harris County. The median household income from 2009 to 2013 was $49,481. Dallas is the city that employs the most people in the county. **Denton County** As of April 2015, the unemployment rate in Dallas County was 3.2 percent. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, there were 205,800 people employed in third quarter of 2014. The median household income from 2009 to 2013 was $74,155, well above the statewide average of $51,900. Carrollton is the city that employs the most people in Denton County. **Tarrant County** Tarrant County was one of five counties in Texas that has an employment rate above 600,000. As of April 2015, the unemployment rate in Tarrant County was 3.7 percent. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, there were 825,600 people employed in third quarter of 2014. The median household income from 2009 to 2013 was $56,853. Arlington is the city that employs the most people in Tarrant County. #### **Taxes** Texans do not pay state or local personal income taxes. It's one of seven states that do not tax wages. As for property taxes, here are a few highlights: Everman, a residential community in Tarrant County and on the southern edge of Fort Worth, has the highest property tax rate in the Dallas-Fort Worth area at 3.43 percent. The lowest is the Denton County town Double Oak, with a 1.97 percent property tax rate. Double Oak resides in the Lewisville School District. If we look at a broader view of which counties have the most communities representing the lowest property tax rates in the Dallas-Fort Worth area (excluding counties other than Dallas, Denton, and Tarrant), Denton owns six of the 10 lowest rates. Dallas has two spots. When looking at the highest property tax rates overall, the top 15 cities/towns are exclusively found in Tarrant and Dallas Counties. However, that needs to be taken with a grain of salt, since what is separating them from the first Denton community is less than one-tenth of a percent. #### **Housing Market** The median values of owner-occupied housing units from 2009 to 2013 were as follows: Dallas County: $128,300 Tarrant County: $136,400 Denton County: $184,100 All of Texas: $128,900 The Dallas area is one of the hottest real estate markets in the country. According to the Standard & Poor’s/Case Shiller Home Price Index, Dallas-area home prices were up 8.7 percent in July, 2015 from the previous year. But predictions have it slowing a bit in 2016 due to slower job growth. Denton County has also been labelled as a seller's market in recent years, with home inventories not keeping up with demand. Here is a look at the top five property value appreciations by city in the three counties: 1. River Oaks (Tarrant County): 19.9 percent 2. Lake Dallas (Denton County): 11.6 percent 3. Sachse (Collin/Dallas Counties) 11.4 percent 4. Everman (Tarrant County): 11.4 percent 5. Richardson (Collin/Dallas Counties): 10.3 percent #### **Recreational Activities** There are plenty of things to do for people living in the Dallas-Forth Worth area. One of the best family outings, fun for kids and adults alike, is spending a day at the zoo. Tarrant County has the Fort Worth Zoo, which boasts that it is open 365 days a year. It is home to 5,000 native and exotic animals. Dallas County has the Dallas Zoo. Located three miles south of downtown Dallas, it is the oldest and largest zoo in Texas Living in a major metropolitan area affords residents access to a number of cultural activities. If art peaks your interest there are plenty of museums that exhibit some of the finest in the world. For instance, there's the Dallas Museum of Art, located in the Arts District of downtown Dallas. Their collection is comprised of more than 24,000 objects, from contemporary to ancient artifacts that date to back as far as 3,000 years BC. Located in Fort Worth, the Amon Carter Museum specializes in American Art, with a focus on the 19th century and first half of the 20th century. The museum's founder, Amon Carter, wanted a place to share his collection of art by Frederic Remington and Charles Marion Russell. Both artists specialized in artistic renderings of the early American West. If music or theater are more your style, Dallas Summer Musicals hosts Broadway productions and other live musical theater. The Bass Performance Hall in Fort Worth (Tarrant County) is the permanent residence of the Fort Worth Symphony Orchestra, Texas Ballet Theater, Fort Worth Opera, and the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition and Cliburn Concerts. Sports fans have the luxury of a team in every major professional league: the Dallas Cowboys (NFL), Dallas Mavericks (NBA), Dallas Stars (NHL), and the Texas Rangers (MLB), who play in Arlington, Texas (Tarrant County). There is plenty to do in the Dallas-Forth Worth area, and plenty of factors to consider before making a choice of where you will be living. Hopefully this helps get you started. Comments? Questions? Let us know on our [feedback page](http://www.cruvita.com/feedback). Never miss a beat! Follow Cruvita on [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/Cruvita.Score), [Twitter](https://www.twitter.com/CruvitaScore), [Google+](https://plus.google.com/111883509410505705073) and [Pinterest](https://www.pinterest.com/cruvita/).
