The top middle school in Dallas County is Mcculloch Intermediate School. Located in Dallas, it is number one in the city, state, and the nation. Click here to view the top middle or intermediate schools in Dallas County.

The top middle school in Denton County is Griffin Middle School in Frisco, Texas. It has achieved an A+ rating and is number one in Frisco, number seven in the state, and number 33 in the nation. To view the top middle, junior high, or intermediate schools in Denton County click here.

The top middle school in Tarrant County is George Dawson Middle in Southlake, Texas. It is number one in Southlake, fourth in the state, and 12th in the nation. To see all the middle, junior high or intermediate school in Tarrant County click here.

Winner: Dallas County

High Schools

The top high school in Dallas County is Highland Park High School. It has an A+ rating, and is first in Dallas, the state, and is second in the nation. To see all the high schools in Dallas County click here.

The top high school in Denton County is Flower Mound High School in Flower Mound, Texas. It received an A+ rating from Cruvita, and is first in Flower Mound, second in Texas, and 71st in the nation. To see all the high schools in Denton County click here.

The top high school in Tarrant County is Keller High School in Keller, Texas. It has an A+ rating and is first in Keller, 31st in Texas, and 436th in the nation. Click here to see all the high schools in Tarrant County, TX.

Winner: Dallas County

While this is only a comparison of the best schools in each county, not the counties as a whole, the results are very interesting. While Dallas County had the fewest A+ rated schools, it still had the best elementary school, middle school, and high school among all three counties.

Job Opportunities

Dallas County

As of April 2015, the unemployment rate in Dallas County was 3.9 percent, much lower than the national average of 6 percent of the time. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, there were 1,558,500 people employed in the third quarter of 2014, which had it ranked second among the largest counties in Texas, right behind Harris County. The median household income from 2009 to 2013 was $49,481. Dallas is the city that employs the most people in the county.

Denton County

As of April 2015, the unemployment rate in Dallas County was 3.2 percent. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, there were 205,800 people employed in third quarter of 2014. The median household income from 2009 to 2013 was $74,155, well above the statewide average of $51,900. Carrollton is the city that employs the most people in Denton County.

Tarrant County

Tarrant County was one of five counties in Texas that has an employment rate above 600,000. As of April 2015, the unemployment rate in Tarrant County was 3.7 percent. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, there were 825,600 people employed in third quarter of 2014. The median household income from 2009 to 2013 was $56,853. Arlington is the city that employs the most people in Tarrant County.

Taxes

Texans do not pay state or local personal income taxes. It's one of seven states that do not tax wages. As for property taxes, here are a few highlights:

Everman, a residential community in Tarrant County and on the southern edge of Fort Worth, has the highest property tax rate in the Dallas-Fort Worth area at 3.43 percent. The lowest is the Denton County town Double Oak, with a 1.97 percent property tax rate. Double Oak resides in the Lewisville School District.

If we look at a broader view of which counties have the most communities representing the lowest property tax rates in the Dallas-Fort Worth area (excluding counties other than Dallas, Denton, and Tarrant), Denton owns six of the 10 lowest rates. Dallas has two spots.

When looking at the highest property tax rates overall, the top 15 cities/towns are exclusively found in Tarrant and Dallas Counties. However, that needs to be taken with a grain of salt, since what is separating them from the first Denton community is less than one-tenth of a percent.

Housing Market

The median values of owner-occupied housing units from 2009 to 2013 were as follows:

Dallas County: $128,300
Tarrant County: $136,400
Denton County: $184,100
All of Texas: $128,900

The Dallas area is one of the hottest real estate markets in the country. According to the Standard & Poor’s/Case Shiller Home Price Index, Dallas-area home prices were up 8.7 percent in July, 2015 from the previous year. But predictions have it slowing a bit in 2016 due to slower job growth.

Denton County has also been labelled as a seller's market in recent years, with home inventories not keeping up with demand. Here is a look at the top five property value appreciations by city in the three counties:

  1. River Oaks (Tarrant County): 19.9 percent
  2. Lake Dallas (Denton County): 11.6 percent
  3. Sachse (Collin/Dallas Counties) 11.4 percent
  4. Everman (Tarrant County): 11.4 percent
  5. Richardson (Collin/Dallas Counties): 10.3 percent

Recreational Activities

There are plenty of things to do for people living in the Dallas-Forth Worth area. One of the best family outings, fun for kids and adults alike, is spending a day at the zoo.

Tarrant County has the Fort Worth Zoo, which boasts that it is open 365 days a year. It is home to 5,000 native and exotic animals. Dallas County has the Dallas Zoo. Located three miles south of downtown Dallas, it is the oldest and largest zoo in Texas

Living in a major metropolitan area affords residents access to a number of cultural activities. If art peaks your interest there are plenty of museums that exhibit some of the finest in the world. For instance, there's the Dallas Museum of Art, located in the Arts District of downtown Dallas. Their collection is comprised of more than 24,000 objects, from contemporary to ancient artifacts that date to back as far as 3,000 years BC.

Located in Fort Worth, the Amon Carter Museum specializes in American Art, with a focus on the 19th century and first half of the 20th century. The museum's founder, Amon Carter, wanted a place to share his collection of art by Frederic Remington and Charles Marion Russell. Both artists specialized in artistic renderings of the early American West.

If music or theater are more your style, Dallas Summer Musicals hosts Broadway productions and other live musical theater. The Bass Performance Hall in Fort Worth (Tarrant County) is the permanent residence of the Fort Worth Symphony Orchestra, Texas Ballet Theater, Fort Worth Opera, and the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition and Cliburn Concerts.

Sports fans have the luxury of a team in every major professional league: the Dallas Cowboys (NFL), Dallas Mavericks (NBA), Dallas Stars (NHL), and the Texas Rangers (MLB), who play in Arlington, Texas (Tarrant County).

There is plenty to do in the Dallas-Forth Worth area, and plenty of factors to consider before making a choice of where you will be living. Hopefully this helps get you started.

Comments? Questions? Let us know on our feedback page.

posts.title: The Best Schools for Homebuyers in Albemarle County, VA
posts.markdown: Albemarle County is located in the state of Virginia and is part of the Charlottesville Metropolitan Area. Albemarle County has a population of about 104,500 people and a median home or condo value of $317,300. The county's seat is Charlottesville. Albemarle County is home to many major highways, waterways and protected areas. The best elementary school for homebuyers in Albemarle County is [Meriwether Lewis Elementary School](http://www.cruvita.com/school/meriwether-lewis-elem-charlottesville-va). It is located at 1610 Owensville Road, Charlottesville, Virginia 22901. Meriwether Lewis Elementary School offers many exclusive programs to its students, such as Dual Language Programs and Bullying Prevention Program. A supporter of a variety of charitable organizations, Meriwether Lewis Elementary School has been a 3-time winner of the Governor's Award for Educational Excellence. The best middle school for homebuyers in Albemarle County is [Joseph T Henley Middle School](http://www.cruvita.com/school/joseph-t-henley-middle-crozet-va). It is located at 5880 Rockfish Gap Turnpike in Crozet, Virginia. Joseph T Henley Middle School offers many after school activities and club, as well as training, safety and summer programs. The best high school for homebuyers in Albemarle County is [Western Albemarle High School](http://www.cruvita.com/school/western-albemarle-high-crozet-va). It is located at 5941 Rockfish Gap Turnpike, Crozet, Virginia, 22932. Western Albemarle High School provides its students with many opportunities to be involved in after school clubs, athletics and peer tutoring programs. Additionally, the school offers students a Math, Engineering and Science Academy for students that show exceptional strength in math and science. posts.title: Why Live in Ann Arbor, Michigan?
posts.markdown: Today, in our continuing series on “Why Live In…,” we explore Ann Arbor, Michigan. Ann Arbor is an independent city in the Ann Arbor Metropolitan Area and is surrounded by several major highways and has many public transportation options, as well as many nature areas. Ann Arbor is home to the University of Michigan which employs over 30,000 people. **Here are a few quick highlights:** * Estimated Population: 114,000 * Estimated Median Household Income: $46,500 * Estimated Home Value: $231,700 * Unemployment Rate: 2.60% There are several great schools and amazing homes in Ann Arbor, Michigan. Eleven of the schools in Ann Arbor have received Cruvita Gold Medals of Excellence at the state level, which you can see by [clicking here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=ann-arbor-mi&type=city), or you can see their position on a map by [clicking here](http://www.cruvita.com/results?location=ann-arbor-mi-c&tab=schools). Interested in the available homes in Ann Arbor, Michigan? You can [click here](http://www.cruvita.com/results?location=ann-arbor-mi-c&tab=homes) to see homes for sale and for rent in the area. You can also contact [Travis Otto](http://www.cruvita.com/profile/travis-l.-otto-6501372107) at (734) 645-1496. *"Ann Arbor boasts some of the worlds best cultural opportunities including world class food, music, art, theater, sports and educational systems. The lively downtown has so much to offer. Charming tree-lined neighborhoods, numerous cultural attractions and an exciting real estate market that continually attracts residents seeking a better quality of life. This is what makes Ann Arbor an ideal place to live, work, and raise a family."* - [Travis Otto](http://www.cruvita.com/profile/travis-l.-otto-6501372107), [Keller Williams Realty Ann Arbor](http://www.travisottohomes.com/). What do you think about Ann Arbor, Michigan? Would you buy a home and raise your family here? Let us know on our [feedback page](http://www.cruvita.com/feedback). Never miss a beat! Follow Cruvita on [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/Cruvita.Score://), [Twitter](https://www.twitter.com/CruvitaScore), [Google+](https://plus.google.com/111883509410505705073) and [Pinterest](https://www.pinterest.com/cruvita/).

posts.title: Why Live in Fort Worth, Texas?
posts.markdown: Today, in our continuing series on “Why Live In…,” we explore Fort Worth, Texas. Fort Worth is an independent city in the Dallas-Fort Worth Metropolitan area and is surrounded by several major highways, has many public transportation options, and is the fifth largest city in Texas. Fort Worth is home to several famed museums and modern architecture, as well as many prominent universities, such as Texas A&M University and Texas Christian University. The top three employers in Fort Worth, Texas are American Airlines, Lockheed Martin and Fort Worth ISD. "Fort Worth is home to some of the world’s best museums, restaurants, music, art, sports and more. The city offers a broad mix of dining options, ranging from original Texas BBQ and steak houses to world class seafood establishments. Home to the TCU Horned Frogs and historic stockyards, the real estate market in Fort Worth is very strong and provides a variety of housing options to meet the needs of all types of home buyers.” - [Michael Reeder](http://www.cruvita.com/profile/Michael-Reeder-0500434) - Owner & Broker of [Chisholm Realtors](http://www.chisholmrealtors.com). **Here are a few quick highlights:** * Estimated Population: 812,000 * Estimated Median Household Income: $52,500 * Estimated Home Value: $122,100 * Unemployment Rate: 3.70% There are several great schools and amazing homes in Fort Worth, Texas. Today, in our continuing series on “Why Live In…,” we explore Fort Worth, Texas. Fort Worth is an independent city in the Dallas-Fort Worth Metropolitan area and is surrounded by several major highways, has many public transportation options, and is the fifth largest city in Texas. Fort Worth is home to several famed museums and modern architecture, as well as many prominent universities, such as Texas A&M University and Texas Christian University. The top three employers in Fort Worth, Texas are American Airlines, Lockheed Martin and Fort Worth ISD.

"Fort Worth is home to some of the world’s best museums, restaurants, music, art, sports and more. The city offers a broad mix of dining options, ranging from original Texas BBQ and steak houses to world class seafood establishments. posts.title: Why Live in Grapevine, Texas?
posts.markdown: Today, in our continuing series on “Why Live In…,” we explore Grapevine, Texas. Grapevine is an independent city in the Dallas-Fort Worth Metropolitan area and is surrounded by several major highways and has many public transportation options, as well as Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport. Grapevine is home to several wineries and a historic downtown center. The top three employers in Grapevine, Texas are the City of Grapevine, Pavestone Manufacturing and Hilton-DFW Lakes. ***“Grapevine provides corporate opportunity and a strong community at a reasonable cost. The Grapevine -Colleyville ISD has some of the best schools in Texas.”** *Says [Tanea Ridenour](http://www.cruvita.com/profile/Tanea-Ridenour-0668591), of [Pioneer Realty Group](http://www.pioneer-realty.com/)*. She also says, **“The Dallas-Fort Worth area consistently ranks near the top of U.S. metros for affordability. With that Grapevine boasts one of the lowest property tax rates in Tarrant County. Moreover, Grapevine provides great tourist attractions like the Great Wolf Lodge and the Gaylord Texan. The Gaylord is practically right across from Grapevine’s famous Main Street which holds restaurants, shopping, wineries and has several festivals every year. Grapevine is a must live in town.”*** **Here are a few quick highlights:** * Estimated Population: 46,000 * Estimated Median Household Income: $76,000 * Estimated Home Value: $233,000 * Unemployment Rate: 2.90% There are several great schools and amazing homes in Grapevine, Texas. posts.title: Why Live in Flower Mound, Texas?
posts.markdown: Today, in our continuing series on “Why Live In…,” we explore Flower Mound, Texas. Flower Mound is suburb town in the Dallas and Fort Worth Metropolitan Area and is served by two major throughways, FM 1171 and FM 2499, both farm-to-market roads. Nestled between the 35W and 35E interstates, Flower Mound has convenient access to both Dallas and Fort Worth. Flower Mound sits along the north shore of Grapevine Lake and is served by many recreational bike and walking paths throughout the town. Home to “The Mound,” a twelve acre hill which grows beautiful flowers in blooming season, Flower Mound, Texas has been voted top 10 Best Dallas Suburbs in recent years. Within the city limits are over fifty public parks and recreation centers. Flower Mound has a major business district and is continuously developing residential and commercial areas. The Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport is just under five miles away, providing steady, opportune growth. Among the town’s top employers are Lewisville Independent School District, Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital, the Town of Flower Mound and Best Buy. **Here are a few quick highlights:** * Estimated Population: 69,700 * Estimated Median Household Income: $121,600 * Estimated Home Value: $270,000 * Unemployment Rate: 3.10% There are several great schools and amazing homes in Flower Mound, Texas. Eighteen of the schools in Flower Mound have received Cruvita Gold Medals of Excellence at the national level, which you can see by [clicking here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=flower-mound-tx&type=city) or you can see their position on a map by [clicking here](http://www.cruvita.com/results?location=flower-mound-tx-c&tab=schools). posts.title: Why Live in Euless, Texas?
posts.markdown: Today, in our continuing series on “Why Live In…,” we explore Euless, Texas. Euless is an independent city in the Dallas and Fort Worth Metropolitan Area. Home to a portion of the Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport, Euless has several major highways, making it convenient to Fort Worth, Dallas and Arlington. Classified as one of the “Mid-Cities,” the region between Dallas and Fort Worth which spans approximately 30 miles, Euless is named after a settler who brought quick community development to the town with his cotton gin business. Each year, Euless hosts a festival called Arbor Daze, which includes concerts, art and business vendors, and many fun activities for children. The festival has been awarded many awards and recognition. Euless’ school district is served by two school districts: the Hurst-Euless-Bedford Independent School District and the Grapevine-Colleyville Independent School District. Among the top employers in Euless are The Hurst-Euless-Bedford Independent School District, Target, Home Depot and Lowe’s Home Improvement. **Here are a few quick highlights:** * Estimated Population: 54,000 * Estimated Median Household Income: $55,000 * Estimated Home Value: $147,000 * Unemployment Rate: 4.50% There are several great schools and amazing homes in Euless, Texas. posts.title: Why Live in Highland Village, Texas?
posts.markdown: Today, in our continuing series on “Why Live In…,” we explore Highland Village, Texas. Highland Village is an independent city in the Dallas and Fort Worth Metropolitan Area. Served by the Denton County Transportation Authority, Highland Village main public transportation systems are the Commuter Express, running south to downtown Dallas and the DCTA A-Train that runs north to Denton. Highland Village sits along the southwest shore of Lewisville Lake. Home to “The Mound,” a twelve acre hill which grows beautiful flowers in blooming season, Flower Mound, Texas has been voted top 10 Best Dallas Suburbs in recent years. Highland Village school district is the Lewisville Independent School District, which serves many other neighboring towns. Its primary high school, Edward S Marcus High School, is located in the nearby town of Flower Mound. Primarily a residential town, Highland Village hosts an annual Hot Air Balloon Festival as well as a Red, White and Blue Music Festival. **Here are a few quick highlights:** * Estimated Population: 16,000 * Estimated Median Household Income: $133,000 * Estimated Home Value: $269,000 * Unemployment Rate: 4.30% There are several great schools and amazing homes in Highland Village, Texas. Four of the schools in Highland Village have received Cruvita Gold Medals of Excellence at the national level, which you can see by [clicking here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=highland-village-tx&type=city) or you can see their position on a map by [clicking here](http://www.cruvita.com/results?location=highland-village-tx-c&tab=schools). posts.markdown: Today, in our continuing series on “Why Live In…,” we explore Keller, Texas.Keller is suburb Fort Worth and is surrounded by several acres of land with several parks and hiking trails. Keller is home to over forty school campuses with over 35,000 students. The top employer is the Keller ISD. *"Location, focus on parks and recreation, well thought of schools and a business friendly climate help land Keller on national "top ten" and "best places to live" lists year after year. Keller's central location in the heart of the Metroplex offers easy access to major business centers and big-city conveniences, while 300 acres of park land and 23 miles of hike and bike trails entice city residents back home at the end of the day. It's an outstanding pairing for quality of life. The strength of the city's excellent economy, increasing home values, great public schools and low crime rates lead home buyers to Keller. It's a growing city, but still small by Metroplex standards, that hasn't forgotten it's small town roots." -*[Cindy Allen](http://www.cruvita.com/profile/cindy-allen-0401593), [Coldwell Banker Residential Brokerage](http://www.dfwmoves.com/). **Here are a few quick highlights:** * Estimated Population: 43,000 * Estimated Median Household Income: $115,000 * Estimated Home Value: $285,000 * Unemployment Rate: 2.90% There are several great schools and amazing homes in Keller, Texas. Thirteen of the schools in Keller have received Cruvita Gold Medals of Excellence at the national level, which you can see, by [clicking here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=keller-tx&type=city) or you can see their position on a map by [clicking here](http://www.cruvita.com/results?location=keller-tx-c&tab=schools). posts.title: Why Live in Oakton, Virginia?
posts.markdown: Today, in our continuing series on “Why Live In…,” we explore Oakton, Virginia. Oakton is a residential suburban area where people enjoy the wooded feel, rolling hills, and the access to many creeks, natural parks and even the W&OD trail for biking or walking. Oakton is conveniently located within Fairfax County. People who live on the south-east end can walk to the Orange Metro line, Vienna, which goes into Washington, D.C.. For anyone driving to work in the city, there is easy access to the famous Route 66, which is the most direct way to get into Washington D.C.. Oakton is close to Reston, Vienna, and Tysons Corner- all great locations for working, shopping, and having fun. Oakton is a few miles away from one of the largest malls in Tysons Corner. ***"Money magazine ranked Oakton #36 out of 100 in its article “Best Places to Live: Money’s list of America’s best small towns.” Although Oakton does not exactly fit the definition of a small town, it is a great place to live. It is rich in equestrian and farming history and that can still be seen apparent along the winding, rolling roads through the wooded neighborhoods. Many lots still exist that accommodate horses and small farms. The large lots, mature trees, close proximity to parks, schools, shopping and easy access to Washington, D.C. has kept Oakton high on the list of many home buyers" says,[Karen Sparks](http://www.cruvita.com/profile/Karen-Sparks-0225089946) of [Keller Williams Realty](http://www.kw.com/kw/).*** **Here are a few quick highlights:** * Estimated Population: 34,000 * Estimated Median Household Income: $120,000 * Estimated Home Value: $720,000 * Unemployment Rate: 3.6% There are several great schools and amazing homes in Oakton, Virginia. Two of the schools in Oakton have received Cruvita Medals of Excellence at the national level, which you can see by [clicking here](http://www.cruvita.com/rankings?location=oakton-va&type=city), or you can see their position on a map by [clicking here](http://www.cruvita.com/results?location=oakton-va-c&tab=schools&edLevel=se:all). Interested in the available homes in Oakton, Virginia? You can [click here](http://www.cruvita.com/results?location=oakton-va-c&tab=homes&edLevel=se:all) to see homes for sale and for rent in the area or you can contact one of our Cruvita Home Sales Experts such as, [Karen Sparks](http://www.cruvita.com/profile/Karen-Sparks-0225089946) at or 703-401-5906. What do you think about Oakton, Virginia? Would you buy a home and raise your family here? Let us know on our [feedback page](http://www.cruvita.com/feedback), on our [Facebook page](https://www.facebook.com/Cruvita.Score) or on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/CruvitaScore)!

posts.title: Why Live in Clarksburg, Maryland?
posts.markdown: Today, in our continuing series on “Why Live In…,” we explore Clarksburg, Maryland. Clarksburg is a small town located in Maryland, along the Potomac River between southern Maryland and northern Virginia, inland from the Chesapeake Bay. Clarksburg is a great place for families with children. Clarksburg has a high rate of owner-occupied single family homes, which tends to reflect stability in the local community. Clarksburg has many people who hop on public transportation, mostly the subway for their daily commute to work. Clarksburg is an extremely ethnically-diverse town. **Here are a few quick highlights:** * Estimated Population: 14,500 * Estimated Median Household Income: $137,000 * Estimated Home Value: $450,000 * Unemployment Rate: 4.1% There are several great schools and amazing homes in Clarksburg, Maryland. posts.title: Seven Things You Can Do to Save Money and Make Your Home more Eco-Friendly
posts.markdown: In this time of stagnant wages and increased cost of living, who isn’t interested in finding ways to cut costs as well as benefiting the environment? There are several steps you can take to ensure lower costs; some require a little investment of time or money upfront, but the long-term benefits make it well worth it. Not only can they benefit you with lower energy bills, but these improvements may also increase your home values and help your chances of selling your home. Here are seven easy and beneficial ways we came up with: 1. **Set your heating and cooling temperature to best suit your needs by investing in a programmable thermostat.** You can program the temperature to be higher (summer) or lower (winter) when you are at work or away on vacation, helping to cut costs and save energy. A programmable thermostat can save you an average of $100/year on your energy bill. 2. **Insulation upgrade.** Nearly half of the homes in the U.S. are under insulated. Make sure your pipes and furnace, as well as attic and any outside walls, are well insulated to help cut down on money from seeping out unnecessarily through the windows and walls. Applying a fresh seal of caulking on the windows and installing door sweeps will also help keep heating and cooling from escaping. 3. **Ceiling fans** are a great way to save costs. In the summer they keep you and your home cool and in the winter you can switch the directions of the fan blades so it circulates the heat back down, allowing the thermostat to register a more accurate reading and keeping the heat where it is needed most – on the lower levels. 4. **Replace old appliances.** Kitchen appliances have drastically increased their energy efficiency over the years due to strict regulations and higher industry standards. So while may you think you’re saving money by keeping an older appliance running, the amount of money needed to run the machine may be costing you more in the long run. 5. **Switch light bulbs.** Replace incandescent bulbs with compact fluorescent lamps (CFLs) or light-emitting diodes (LEDs). CFLs last ten times longer than incandescent bulbs and use 75% less energy. LED bulbs are mercury-free and last up to five times longer than CFLs. The price of running a 60-Watt incandescent bulb for 20 years (based on 6 hours per day) is $360 compare that to running a 60-Watt LED equivalent for the same amount of time is only $72. Imagine how much you could save by replacing every bulb in your home with LEDs over the course of many years! 6. **Solar Power where possible.** Solar panels, which can be used to heat water or generate electricity, can save money on your energy bills in the long run, lower your fossil fuel usage, and may qualify for tax incentives. This technology is still fairly new and although costs have decreased, it is still quite an investment. You can have an expert energy auditor come out and inform you of how much you’ll actually save with the use, sometimes free of cost to you. 7. **Check with your energy provider to see if you qualify for a rebate** for installing certain qualifying appliances or equipment. For example Columbia Gas of Virginia will give their residential customers a $300 rebate/unit for installing a high-efficiency gas furnace if it has an AFUE greater than or equal to 90% and a $50 rebate/unit for the purchase and installation of a Smart Thermostat from a pre-approved list. What do you think about these seven ways to make your home more eco-friendly? Let us know on our [feedback page](http://www.cruvita.com/feedback), on our [Facebook page](https://www.facebook.com/Cruvita.Score) or on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/CruvitaScore)! *Article by: Aisha Khan *
posts.html:
In this time of stagnant wages and increased cost of living, who isn’t interested in finding ways to cut costs as well as benefiting the environment? There are several steps you can take to ensure lower costs; some require a little investment of time or money upfront, but the long-term benefits make it well worth it. Not only can they benefit you with lower energy bills, but these improvements may also increase your home values and help your chances of selling your home. Here are seven easy and beneficial ways we came up with:

  1. Set your heating and cooling temperature to best suit your needs by investing in a programmable thermostat. You can program the temperature to be higher (summer) or lower (winter) when you are at work or away on vacation, helping to cut costs and save energy. A programmable thermostat can save you an average of $100/year on your energy bill.

  2. Insulation upgrade. Nearly half of the homes in the U.S. are under insulated. Make sure your pipes and furnace, as well as attic and any outside walls, are well insulated to help cut down on money from seeping out unnecessarily through the windows and walls. Applying a fresh seal of caulking on the windows and installing door sweeps will also help keep heating and cooling from escaping.

  3. Ceiling fans are a great way to save costs. In the summer they keep you and your home cool and in the winter you can switch the directions of the fan blades so it circulates the heat back down, allowing the thermostat to register a more accurate reading and keeping the heat where it is needed most – on the lower levels.

  4. Replace old appliances. Kitchen appliances have drastically increased their energy efficiency over the years due to strict regulations and higher industry standards. So while may you think you’re saving money by keeping an older appliance running, the amount of money needed to run the machine may be costing you more in the long run.

  5. Switch light bulbs. Replace incandescent bulbs with compact fluorescent lamps (CFLs) or light-emitting diodes (LEDs). CFLs last ten times longer than incandescent bulbs and use 75% less energy. LED bulbs are mercury-free and last up to five times longer than CFLs. The price of running a 60-Watt incandescent bulb for 20 years (based on 6 hours per day) is $360 compare that to running a 60-Watt LED equivalent for the same amount of time is only $72. Imagine how much you could save by replacing every bulb in your home with LEDs over the course of many years!

  6. Solar Power where possible. Solar panels, which can be used to heat water or generate electricity, can save money on your energy bills in the long run, lower your fossil fuel usage, and may qualify for tax incentives. This technology is still fairly new and although costs have decreased, it is still quite an investment. You can have an expert energy auditor come out and inform you of how much you’ll actually save with the use, sometimes free of cost to you.

  7. Check with your energy provider to see if you qualify for a rebate for installing certain qualifying appliances or equipment. For example Columbia Gas of Virginia will give their residential customers a $300 rebate/unit for installing a high-efficiency gas furnace if it has an AFUE greater than or equal to 90% and a $50 rebate/unit for the purchase and installation of a Smart Thermostat from a pre-approved list.

What do you think about these seven ways to make your home more eco-friendly?

Let us know on our feedback page, on our Facebook page or on Twitter!

posts.title: New Tax Credit for First-time Homebuyers
posts.markdown: Summer is typically one of the busiest homebuying seasons across the United States, and sales of both new and existing homes have been on a rollercoaster ride for the past few months. First-time homebuyers face a number of challenges and one of the primary issues is affordability. However, there are a number of unique programs that can help save first-time buyers money. If you’re a first-time homebuyer searching for a new home and wanting to save money, there’s a federal tax credit program that could work for you! Mortgage Credit Certificates, known commonly as MCCs, are available in many states throughout the country. Through the MCC program, eligible first-time homebuyers can save thousands of dollars by reducing the amount they owe on their federal income tax. MCCs are typically administered by a state’s housing/development agency, such as the [Virginia Housing Development Authority](http://www.vhda.com/), a self-supporting, not-for-profit organization created by the Commonwealth of Virginia in 1972 to help Virginians attain quality, affordable housing. #### You could save thousands: If you’re eligible, an MCC could reduce the amount of federal income tax you owe, every year that you live in your house! Unlike an income tax deduction, an MCC is a dollar-for-dollar credit against your federal income tax liability. ####How an MCC could save you money: * The amount of the credit can vary by state and in Virginia it is equal to 20% of your annual mortgage interest. * The amount of the remaining deduction also varies by state. In Virginia, the remaining 80% can still be taken as a deduction. * An MCC is good for the life of your mortgage, for as long as you live in your home. ####How to apply for an MCC: Be sure to ask your lender or Realtor about an MCC when you first apply for your mortgage. You can also contact your state’s housing/development agency to inquire about an MCC. In Virginia, for example, you can find an approved MCC lender and get more information about MCCs at [VirginiaMCC.com](http://www.virginiamcc.com/). MCCs are a great option for many people, but they may not make the most sense for everyone. State housing/development agencies typically determine whether homebuyers qualify for MCCs under the Internal Revenue Code, but homebuyers must determine for themselves whether an MCC will save them money and how valuable an MCC will be for them over the life of their loan. Remember to talk to your tax advisor to see whether an MCC will save you money and how valuable an MCC will be for you over the life of your loan. To see if you’re eligible for an MCC, talk to your mortgage lender today and you could be one step closer to owning your first home! If you are still looking for the right home seach on [Cruvita.com](http://www.cruvita.com)! Let us know on our [feedback page](http://www.cruvita.com/feedback). Never miss a beat! Follow Cruvita on [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/Cruvita.Score://), [Twitter](https://www.twitter.com/CruvitaScore), [Google+](https://plus.google.com/111883509410505705073) and [Pinterest](https://www.pinterest.com/cruvita/).

Summer is typically one of the busiest homebuying seasons across the United States, and sales of both new and existing homes have been on a rollercoaster ride for the past few months.

First-time homebuyers face a number of challenges and one of the primary issues is affordability. However, there are a number of unique programs that can help save first-time buyers money. If you’re a first-time homebuyer searching for a new home and wanting to save money, there’s a federal tax credit program that could work for you!

Mortgage Credit Certificates, known commonly as MCCs, are available in many states throughout the country. Through the MCC program, eligible first-time homebuyers can save thousands of dollars by reducing the amount they owe on their federal income tax.

MCCs are typically administered by a state’s housing/development agency, such as the Virginia Housing Development Authority, a self-supporting, not-for-profit organization created by the Commonwealth of Virginia in 1972 to help Virginians attain quality, affordable housing.

You could save thousands:

If you’re eligible, an MCC could reduce the amount of federal income tax you owe, every year that you live in your house! Unlike an income tax deduction, an MCC is a dollar-for-dollar credit against your federal income tax liability.

How an MCC could save you money:

  • The amount of the credit can vary by state and in Virginia it is equal to 20% of your annual mortgage interest.
  • The amount of the remaining deduction also varies by state. In Virginia, the remaining 80% can still be taken as a deduction.
  • An MCC is good for the life of your mortgage, for as long as you live in your home.

How to apply for an MCC:

Be sure to ask your lender or Realtor about an MCC when you first apply for your mortgage. You can also contact your state’s housing/development agency to inquire about an MCC. In Virginia, for example, you can find an approved MCC lender and get more information about MCCs at VirginiaMCC.com.

MCCs are a great option for many people, but they may not make the most sense for everyone. State housing/development agencies typically determine whether homebuyers qualify for MCCs under the Internal Revenue Code, but homebuyers must determine for themselves whether an MCC will save them money and how valuable an MCC will be for them over the life of their loan. Remember to talk to your tax advisor to see whether an MCC will save you money and how valuable an MCC will be for you over the life of your loan.

To see if you’re eligible for an MCC, talk to your mortgage lender today and you could be one step closer to owning your first home!

posts.title: Three Ways First-time Homebuyers  Can Take Their Best  Shot at Homeownership
posts.markdown: If you’re thinking about buying your first home, you may be wondering where the down payment will come from, how much you can afford, and whether you’re prepared for the responsibilities of homeownership. If that sounds like you, there are a number of programs available to help. From California to New York and Texas to Michigan, housing/development agencies offer a number of programs to assist first-time homebuyers. In Virginia, for example, the Virginia Housing Development Authority (VHDA) offers programs to help Virginians attain quality, affordable housing. Here are three programs that are common in many states and can help make your dream of homeownership a reality: 1. **Federal Tax Credit for First-time Homebuyers.** If you’re eligible, a Mortgage Credit Certificate (MCC) could save you thousands of dollars by reducing the amount of federal income tax you owe. Unlike an income tax deduction, an MCC is a dollar-for-dollar credit against your federal income tax liability. The MCC is effective for the life of your mortgage, so you could potentially save money on your taxes every year, for as long as you live in your home. You must ask about an MCC when you first apply for a mortgage — if you wait until after you’ve applied, it will be too late! 2. **Homebuyer Class.** Many local or state housing/development agencies or local nonprofit organizations offer in-depth courses for homebuyers. They cover topics such as credit, setting up a spending plan, working with a lender and real estate agent, the home inspection and the closing process. Classes may be offered in multiple languages and students may be able to choose online or classroom training. Each state will vary, but in Virginia, you can find a class or take it online at [vhda.com/FreeClass](http://www.vhda.com/Homebuyers/HomeownershipEdu/Pages/HomeownershipEdu.aspx). 3. **Affordable Home Mortgages.** Local or state housing/development agencies typically offer a variety of home mortgage loans for first-time homebuyers. Some of these loans are fixed-rate, 30-year mortgages, and some don’t require a down payment. Many loans have maximum income and sales price limits and/or loan limits, which vary according to where the home is located. Contact your local or state housing/development agency to get all the details on these affordable home mortgages. Your mortgage lender can provide this information as well. Financing your home is just one part of the process. There are lots of tools and resources, like [Cruvita](http://www.Cruvita.com), that can help you find your next home. With lenders, real estate agents and programs like these, homebuyers can take their best shot at homeownership, and hopefully take home a win! posts.html:
If you’re thinking about buying your first home, you may be wondering where the down payment will come from, how much you can afford, and whether you’re prepared for the responsibilities of homeownership. If that sounds like you, there are a number of programs available to help. From California to New York and Texas to Michigan, housing/development agencies offer a number of programs to assist first-time homebuyers. In Virginia, for example, the Virginia Housing Development Authority (VHDA) offers programs to help Virginians attain quality, affordable housing.

Here are three programs that are common in many states and can help make your dream of homeownership a reality:

  1. Federal Tax Credit for First-time Homebuyers.
    If you’re eligible, a Mortgage Credit Certificate (MCC) could save you thousands of dollars by reducing the amount of federal income tax you owe. Unlike an income tax deduction, an MCC is a dollar-for-dollar credit against your federal income tax liability. The MCC is effective for the life of your mortgage, so you could potentially save money on your taxes every year, for as long as you live in your home. You must ask about an MCC when you first apply for a mortgage — if you wait until after you’ve applied, it will be too late!

  2. Homebuyer Class.
    Many local or state housing/development agencies or local nonprofit organizations offer in-depth courses for homebuyers. They cover topics such as credit, setting up a spending plan, working with a lender and real estate agent, the home inspection and the closing process. Classes may be offered in multiple languages and students may be able to choose online or classroom training. Each state will vary, but in Virginia, you can find a class or take it online at vhda.com/FreeClass.

  3. Affordable Home Mortgages.
    Local or state housing/development agencies typically offer a variety of home mortgage loans for first-time homebuyers. Some of these loans are fixed-rate, 30-year mortgages, and some don’t require a down payment. Many loans have maximum income and sales price limits and/or loan limits, which vary according to where the home is located. Contact your local or state housing/development agency to get all the details on these affordable home mortgages. Your mortgage lender can provide this information as well.

Financing your home is just one part of the process. There are lots of tools and resources, like Cruvita, that can help you find your next home. With lenders, real estate agents and programs like these, homebuyers can take their best shot at homeownership, and hopefully take home a win!

If you are still looking for the right home search on Cruvita.com!

Let us know on our feedback page.

posts.title: Top 30 Elementary Schools in Hillsborough County, Florida for Homebuyers
posts.markdown:
Hillsborough County is located in the state of Florida. Hillsborough County was founded 1834. The population is 1.300 million and unemployment rate is 4.8%. The county seat and largest city is Tampa. Hillsborough County is home to Alafia River State Park and Hillsborough River State Parks. It is also home to the largest natural spring in Florida, C.W. Bill Young Regional Reservoir and Lithia Springs. Hillsborough County is home to several Universities and Colleges; University of Tampa, University of South Florida, Hillsborough Community College and many more. Hillsborough County has lots of fun for the family to do; Busch Gardens Tampa Bay, Florida Aquarium, Lowry Park Zoo, Adventure Island, Tampa Convention Center and many more attractions. Pinellas County is located in the state of Florida. Pinellas County was founded in 1911. Pinellas County was founded in 1911. The county seat is Clearwater and its largest city is St. Petersburg. The population is 930,000 and unemployment rate is 4.8%. Pinellas County has three of the top beaches in the nation, Fort De Soto Park, Clearwater and Caladesi Island State Park. There are many other beautiful beaches; Indian Rocks, Madeira and several more where you can enjoy swimming, boating and fishing. Pinellas County has 35 miles of powdery white beaches. Pinellas County is home to University of South Florida St.Petersburg, St. Petersburg College, Eckerd College and many more. Pinellas has 43 golf courses. Sarasota County is located in the state of Florida. Sarasota County was founded in 1921. The population is about 390,000. The unemployment rate is at 5 %. Sarasota is a popular city on the Gulf Coast of Southwest Florida. The largest city in Sarasota County is North Port. There are plenty of great places to visit in Sarasota County; The Ringling, Marie Selby Botanical Gardens, The Ca d’Zan Mansion, Sarasota National Cemetery, Mote Marine Laboratory and Aquarium, Myakka River State Park, Sarasota Classic Car Museum, Siesta Beach, Lido Key, Don Pedro Island State Park and there are many more fun attractions. Sarasota County is home to great Universities and Colleges; Ringling College of Art and Design, New College of Florida, University of South Florida Sarasota, Fashion Focus Hair Academy, Florida State University/Asolo Conservatory for Actor Training and many more. posts.title: Top Elementary Schools in Volusia County Florida for Homebuyers
posts.markdown:
Volusia County is located in the state of Florida. Volusia County was founded in 1854. The population is approximately 500,000 and unemployment rate is at 5.5%. Volusia County is home to lots of beautiful beaches; Daytona Beach, New Smyrna Beach, Ormond Beach and many others. Lake George, Lake Monroe, DeLeon Springs, Mosquito Lagoon, Lake Helen, Holy Hill, Oak Hill, Lake Harney are great locations for fishing, boating, scuba diving, sailing, alligators, kayak, horseback riding and many other activities. Enjoy an educational tour of a variety of Museums in Volusia County; DeLand House Museum, African American Museum of the Arts, Southeast Museum of Photography, Museum of Arts and Sciences and many more. Volusia County has a wide range of Colleges and Universities in the area; Daytona State College, Stetson University, Bethune Cookman University, Embry Riddle Aeronautical University, Daytona College and few more Listed below are the 20 best elementary schools for homebuyers in Volusia County, Florida. Two of the schools received a Cruvita Medal of Excellence at the national level. posts.title: Seminole County Florida's Best Elementary Schools for Homebuyers
posts.markdown:
Seminole County is located in the state of Florida. Seminole County was founded in 1913. The population is approximately 440,000 and the unemployment rate is at 4.6%. Its county seat and largest city is Sanford. Central Florida Zoo and Botanical Gardens, Rock Springs Run State Reserve, Altamonte Mall, Museum of the Apopkans, and Lake Jesup are all great places to visit. Seminole County has a few great colleges; Seminole State College of Florida, Paul Mitchell the School-Orlando, City College, ITT Technical Institute-Lake Mary and many more. Lake County is located in the state of Florida. Lake County was founded in 1887. The population is approximately 310,000 and unemployment rate is at 5.2%. Its county seat is Tavares and its largest city is Clermont.
